title: China sends 50 tons of in-kind flood relief assistance to Pakistan (Linked to Project #53533)
description: To assist the Pakistani people and the army in fighting the floods, the Chinese People's Liberation Army sent in an international rescue medical team of 50 people, who also carried along with them 50 tons of emergency relief materials. Linked to project #53533
sources: http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t869340.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t869339.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://reliefweb.int/report/pakistan/chinese-army-send-medical-team-pakistan-humanitarian-relief, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://tribune.com.pk/story/277959/floods-2011-china-to-send-50-relief-workers/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: China sent a medical team to the town of Kunri. It is located in Umerkat District, and the ADM2 is Mirpur Khas Division, which was coded.
name: Mirpur Khas

title: Chinese bank syndicate provides $200 million loan for coal mine to support a coal-fired power plant at Thar Block II (linked to #53968 and #35127)
description:
Sindh Engro Coal Mining Company Limited (SECMC) is a joint venture — between Government of Sindh (54.7%), Engro Powergen Limited (EPL) (11.9%) and its Affiliate Engro Powergen Thar Limited (EPTL) (11.9%), Habib Bank Limited (9.5%), Hub Power Company Ltd (8%), China Machinery Engineering Corporation (4%) — that is responsible for developing a coal mine of 3.8 million tonnes per annum capacity. This coal mine will supply coal to a 2 X 330 (660MW) mine mouth circulating fluidized bed technology coal-based power plant (captured in #35127), which is located at Thar Block II, 25 kilometer from the city of Islamkot, near the village of Singharo-Bitra Tharparkar District and Sindh Province.
 
 The coal will initially be supplied to Engro Powergen Thar (Private) Limited (EPTL), per a Coal Supply Agreement dated June 7, 2015. However, SECMC plans to expand its mining capacity to 7.6 metric tons per annum to cater for the two additional 330MW power plants run by Thar Energy Limited and ThalNova Power Thar (Pvt.) Limited. Thar Block II is a 95.5 square kilometer (km2) area of the Thar coalfield, which has total lignite reserves of 175 billion tons which can be utilized to produce 100,000 Megawatt (MW) for over 200 years. The project will cost $911m million and it is being financed with 75% debt and 25% equity. 
 
 On December 21, 2015, Sindh Engro Coal Mining Company (SECMC) signed three loan facility agreements: a syndicated loan facility agreement with 8 commercial banks (Habib Bank Limited, United Bank Limited, Bank Alfalah Limited, Askari Bank Limited, Sindh Bank Limited, Bank of Punjab, NIB Bank Limited, and Habib Metropolitan Bank) worth 40 million Pakistani rupees with a 14 year maturity, 4 year grace period, and interest rate of 6-month KIBOR plus a 1.75% margin; an Islamic syndicated finance agreement with three banks (Meezan Bank Limited, Faysal Bank Limited, and Habib Bank Limited) worth 12 million Pakistani rupees with a 14 year maturity, 4 year grace period, and interest rate of 6-month KIBOR plus a 1.75% margin; and a $200 million (USD-denominated) syndicated loan facility with ICBC, China Construction Bank and China Development Bank that has a 14 year maturity, 4 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.485%) plus a 3.3% margin. 
 
 This project records the debt financing component. The equity financing component can be found in Project #53968. China Machinery Engineering Corporation and China-East Resources Import & Export Company are the EPC contractors responsible for project implementation. Project implementation began on April 13, 2016. In September 2017, it was reported project was in the process of dewatering three of the aquifers in the mine, with all challenges being addressed in a timely manner. The water drained from the three aquifers would recycled later for the operational work of the Thar Coal Block-II power projects. In December 2017, it was reported that half of the work on That Coal Block-II was completed and that the project was to be completed and functioning by August 2019 and have a capacity of 1.32 gigawatts but divided into four mine-mouth power plants and mining 7.6 million tonnes of coal per year. The project ultimately reached its commercial operation date (COD) on July 10, 2019
sources: https://www.dropbox.com/s/q5lthzouc1lftfi/IJGlobal%20-%20Thar%20Coal%20Block%20II%20Mine%20-%20Pakistan.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASMESG0020170911ed990000h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/v20xyj2myrd4j38/Growth%20Aspirations%20%E2%80%93%20Hubco.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.secmc.com.pk/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/SECMC_Annual_Report_2018.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.engroenergy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/SECMC-Accounts-Dec-2016-Consolidated-Signed-Copy-FINAL.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/ghw1bp97oql2tpw/SECMC-ANNUAL-REPORT-2016.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Mirpur Khas is coded for this project since the coal mine is located in this division. The location of the coal mines can be found by searching Engro Coal Mines into google maps
name: Mirpur Khas

title: China donates 7,000 tents to Pakistan for flood relief (linked to project #53535)
description: On September 11, 2011, the Chinese Government pledged to provide emergency humanitarian aid worth RMB 30 million (4.7 million USD) consisting of 7,000 tents and a total of nine aircraft sorties to the Pakistani Government to help the flood relief efforts. The aid was delivered by nine planes in two batches. The first batch was delivered by air in Karachi on September 23, 2011 and the second batch on September 24, 2011. In addition, China has also provided in-cash assistance for Pakistan of US$5 million, captured in Project #53535
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASPKOB0020110927e79r00015&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.aaj.tv/2011/09/chinese-aid-for-flood-victims-reaches-pakistan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=155157, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t869340.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://tribune.com.pk/story/269170/china-to-give-5million-aid-in-cash-to-pakistan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.brecorder.com/general-news/single/599/172/1234608/?date=2011-09-24, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/pakistan/chinese-army-send-medical-team-pakistan-humanitarian-relief, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://tribune.com.pk/story/277959/floods-2011-china-to-send-50-relief-workers/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Also coded the Mirpur Khas Division since the articel stated some of the aid would be transferred to the city of Kunry in southern Sindh. Kunry/Kunri is town located in the Umarkot District which is in the Mirpur Khas Division
name: Mirpur Khas

title: [CPEC] China funds Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob Project in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob project. According to the express tribune report, the western route of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), including the Khan-Zhob project, is going to be completed by the end of 2018 along with other 11 mega projects which were initiated in 2015-16. In January 2017, Pakistan's Under Communications Division provided 120 million Pakistani rupees for the Zhob Mughal Kot road. The division also contributed 40 million Pakistani rupees for the rehabilitation of DI Khan Mughal Kot road. As of Nov 2018, CPEC website only indicates that Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and the LOI has been forwarded to Chinese side. No other progress is indicated. A second CPEC website puts the project cost at US$195 million. It also suggests that the project is an 'upgradation of D.I.Khan - Zhob Phase I.' It is unclear whether the transaction amount is provided solely by China and in what form the fund is provided. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for FY 2017/18 lists this project as a 'Dualization of Yarik - Mughal Kot-Zhob Section of N-50'. It includes the Zhob Bypass. Cross-checking with the CPEC website confirms they are the same project. According to the source, Pakistan received no loan assistance in FY 2016/17 for the project, and are estimating loans of 4,000 million Pakistan rupees in FY 2017/18.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASPTOD0020161230eccu0002h&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://timesofislamabad.com/05-Sep-2018/cpec-western-route-faces-setback, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://tribune.com.pk/story/1633076/1-cpec-western-route-completed-end-year/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/70, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/85, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.cpecinfo.com/cpec-news-detail?id=NTE0MA==, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/13-Transport_and_Communications.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistant_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sjbipp.org/publications/AR/reports/AR-10-17.pdf , Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/70, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://na.gov.pk/uploads/documents/questions/1516343781_434.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/budget/Estimates_of_Foreign_Assistant_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/Economic_Survey_2017_18.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cpec.gov.pk/brain/public/uploads/psdp-projects/CPEC_Projects_2017-18.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=NINTPK0020170118ed1i00035&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: FATA is coded in this row. N50 road runs through this division.
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China government grants RMB 800 million for IDPs/TDPs and Social Sector Projects of FATA (linked to project #52649)
description: On April 20, 2015, China government signed an agreement with Pakistan government to provide missing an RMB 800 million grant commitment for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and temporarily displaced persons (TDPs) and social sector projects in the Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). This region had been the site of clashes between the Pakistani Military and the Taliban, and over 1.5 million people were displaced. It was followed by an additional US$10 million donation (project #52649).
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/SiteImage/Misc/files/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://tribune.com.pk/story/921343/china-pledges-10-million-special-grant-to-pakistan, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.aa.com.tr/en/world/china-donates-10m-for-pakistan-s-internally-displaced/25712, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: China gave money to help temporarily displaced people in FATA. While the FATA geoboundary exists, it is important to note that FATA was merged with Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in 2018 and the geoboundaries have not yet been updated. However, this project specifically dealt with FATA so the geoboundary was used.
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China donates 5 million Pakistani Rupee for resettlement of internal displaced persons in Pakistan
description: On July 9, 2014, the Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan, Sun Weidong, presented a donation of 5 million Pakistani Rupees to a Pakistani official on behalf of the Chinese embassy for the resettlement of internal displaced persons in Pakistan. The check was accepted by Abdul Qadir Baloch, minister of Pakistan's Ministry of States and Frontier Regions (SAFRON) for the resettlement of the internally displaced persons (IDPs) from North Waziristan The surge in internally displaced population was caused by Operation Zarb-e-Azb, a military campaign launched by the Pakistani armed forces on June 15 against domestic local militant groups hiding in North Waziristan tribal regions. SAFRON officials reported that more than 833,000 people have been registered as IDPs as a result of the operation.
sources: http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t1172925.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://nation.com.pk/10-Jul-2014/china-reassures-pakistan-on-economic-package, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-islamabad-pakistan-9th-july-2014-chinese-ambassador-to-pakistan-sun-71609402.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://dailyfrontierstar.com/%EF%BB%BFchinese-embassy-in-pakistan-donates-50000-to-nwa-idps/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: China donated 5 million rupees to help resettle Afghan refugees in North Waziristan. It is located in Bannu Division.
name: Bannu

title: China Eximbank provides $1.79 billion preferential buyer’s credit loan for Sukkur-Multan Section of Karachi-Lahore Highway Project (Linked to Project ID #39013 and #54415)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019. More locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/peshawar-karachi-motorway-multan-sukkur-section-construction/1f700a87-cdc9-414a-8353-ce68ddf9f5fd/

http://nha.gov.pk/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Confirmed-Minutes-235-Executive-Board-Meeting-of-NHA.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://nha.gov.pk/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Confirmed-Minutes-236-Executive-Board-Meeting-of-NHA1.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); name: Bahawalpur

title: China Exim Bank loans RMB 100 million to 100 MW Crest Energy Pakistan Limited Solar Power Plant at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #53988 and #54284) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Crest Energy Pakistan Limited (CEPL) is a special purpose vehicle designed to facilitate the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. On December 21, 2015, CEPL signed a Term Facility Agreement with China EXIM Bank and China Bohai Co Limited. Financial closure was reached on December 28, 2015. On June 27, 2015, CEPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd. and MCC Ruba International Construction Company Pvt. Ltd. to build, own, and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility in the Solar Park. The cumulative EPC contract value is 984 Million RMB. The Commercial Operations Date for this CEPL Solar Power plant was July 31, 2016. The total project cost is 149.457 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio of 75:25. China EXIM Bank made 2 loans to CEPL - one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million (equivalent to 15.196 million USD) and another one denominated in USD, worth 40.810 Million USD (captured in #53988). China Bohai Bank made 1 loan to CEPL, denominated in USD and worth 56.190 million USD (captured in #54284). These two loans make up the 75% debt component of the overall project. The interest rate for Exim Bank's RMB denominated loan is 2.65%. The Interest rate for Exim Bank's USD denominated loan is 5.6916%, and the interest rate for China Bohai Bank's loan is 5.0958%. This projects records the RMB denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
sources: http://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Crest%20Energy%20Pakistan%20Limited/2017/TRF-318%20CEPL%20COD%2018875-77%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.nepra.org.pk/Licences/Generation/RE-2006/Crest%20Energy%20Solar/LAG-294%20CREST%20ENERGY%20PL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209851-57.PDF , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Coded the Bahawalpur District since the Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park is found in this district
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 100 million loan for 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #53989 and #54286) (CPEC, IPP)
description: On December 21, 2015, Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited (BGEPL) signed three loan agreements with China Eximbank and Bank of Jiangsu Co Limited for the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, within Bahawalpur District in the Province of Punjab. BGEPL later signed Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd. This $150.269 million project was implemented on a build, own and operate (BOO) basis and it was financed according to a debt-equity ratio of 81:19. China Eximbank gave 2 loans, one RMB-denominated worth 100 million that carried a 2.65% interest rate and 10 year maturity, and another denominated in USD worth $49.060 million that carried an 5.0058%. The Bank of Jiangsu gave a third loan, denominated in USD, which worth 64.440 million (5.0958% interest rate) (captured in #54286). This projects records the RMB-denominated loan from China Eximbank. Project ID#53989 records the USD-denominated loan from China Eximbank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. The project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on July 31, 2016. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
sources: http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/xazg520wfxwtg29/D-2772-16-03-2015-BEST%20GREEN%20EPL.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/4zkiyxvpxj1tm9b/TRF-317%20BGEPL%20COD%2018683-65%2016-11-2017.PDF?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank and CDB provide $62.6 million syndicated loan to 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant at the Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project ID#50939 and #53985) (CPEC, IPP)
description:
On October 16, 2015, Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited (ASDPL) — a project company (special purpose vehicle) established by Zonergy Company Limited — signed an RMB 400 million syndicated loan agreement (project ID#53985) and a $62.6 million syndicated loan agreement (this project) with China Eximbank and China Development Bank. The RMB-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 2.65% and the USD-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 4.96%. The total project cost was $149.154 million and it was financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 79:21. 
 
 The project was implemented on a build-own-operate (BOT) basis and it involved the construction of a 100 MW solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd were the EPC contractors. This project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on May 31, 2016.
 
 Staff_Note: This 100 MW solar PV power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. More detailed locational coordinates can be found at https://www.nepra.org.pk/licensing/Licences/Generation/RE-2006/Appolo%20Development%20Solar/LAG-296%20APPOLO%20SDPL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209859-65.PDF.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Appolo%20Solar%20Development%20Pakistan%20Limited/TRF-316%20ASDPL%20COD%2018869-71%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://file.finance.sina.com.cn/211.154.219.97:9494/MRGG/BOND/2019/2019-6/2019-06-17/11194690.PDF, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com//money/2017-03/05/c_129506810.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/mmv20srqe0ufttw/TRF-316%20ASDPL%20COD%2018869-71%2016-11-2017.PDF?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/y4fjctt5buk5ims/LAG-296%20APPOLO%20SDPL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209859-65.PDF?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

According to the project description, the power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam solar park which can be found using google maps, so Bahawalpur division is coded for this project. The location source in the project description is broken.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan for Sukkur-Multan Section of Karachi-Lahore Highway Project (Linked to Project ID #54415 and #54416)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019.

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million loan for 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #54285 and #54286) (CPEC, IPP)
description: On December 21, 2015, Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited (BGEPL) signed three loan agreements with China Eximbank and Bank of Jiangsu Co Limited for the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, within Bahawalpur District in the Province of Punjab. BGEPL later signed Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd. This $150.269 million project was implemented on a build, own and operate (BOO) basis and it was financed according to a debt-equity ratio of 81:19. China Eximbank gave 2 loans, one RMB-denominated worth 100 million that carried a 2.65% interest rate, and another denominated in USD worth $49.060 million that carried an 5.0058%. The Bank of Jiangsu gave a third loan, denominated in USD, which worth 64.440 million (5.0958% interest rate) (captured in #54286). This projects records the USD-denominated loan from China Eximbank. Project ID#54285 records the RMB-denominated loan from China Eximbank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. The project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on July 31, 2016. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Best%20Green%20Energy%20Pakistan%20Limited/2017/TRF-317%20BGEPL%20COD%2018683-65%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/4zkiyxvpxj1tm9b/TRF-317%20BGEPL%20COD%2018683-65%2016-11-2017.PDF?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/xazg520wfxwtg29/D-2772-16-03-2015-BEST%20GREEN%20EPL.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Bahawalpur division is coded for this project since the power plant is located here. According to the project description, the power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam solar park which can be found using google maps.
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank and CDB provide RMB 400 million syndicated loan to 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant at the Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939 and #54287) (CPEC, IPP)
description:
On October 16, 2015, Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited (ASDPL) — a project company (special purpose vehicle) established by Zonergy Company Limited — signed an RMB 400 million syndicated loan agreement (this record) and a $62.6 million syndicated loan agreement (project ID#54287) with China Eximbank and China Development Bank. The RMB-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 2.65% and the USD-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 4.96%. The total project cost was $149.154 million and it was financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 79:21. 
 
 The project was implemented on a build-own-operate (BOT) basis and it involved the construction of a 100 MW solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd were the EPC contractors. This project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on May 31, 2016.
 
 Staff_Note: This 100 MW solar PV power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. More detailed locational coordinates can be found at https://www.nepra.org.pk/licensing/Licences/Generation/RE-2006/Appolo%20Development%20Solar/LAG-296%20APPOLO%20SDPL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209859-65.PDF.
sources: https://nepra.org.pk/Tariff/IPPs/002%20Solar%20IPPs/Appolo%20Solar%20Development%20Pakistan%20Limited/TRF-316%20ASDPL%20COD%2018869-71%2016-11-2017.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eximbank.gov.cn/aboutExim/annals/2015/201807/P020180712414684910260.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.xinhuanet.com//money/2017-03/05/c_129506810.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/mmv20srqe0ufttw/TRF-316%20ASDPL%20COD%2018869-71%2016-11-2017.PDF?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes:
According to the project description, the power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam solar park which can be found using google maps, so Bahawalpur division is coded for this project. The location source in the project description is broken.
 note: this project id captures the $400 million loan
name: Bahawalpur

title: China grants 2 million RMB to Afghan refugees in Pakistan
description: In April, 2001, China pledged 2 million RMB yuan to support Afghan refugees living in Peshawar, Pakistan, which was then officially donated in July of that year. On 6th April 2001, in Islamabad, An Min (visiting Chinese vice Minister for Trade & Economic Cooperation) and Nawid Ahsan (Secretary of Economic affairs division) signed and exchanged letters for donation of relief items worth RMB Yuan 2.0 million for the Afghan Refugees in Pakistan. On 5th July 2001, Lu Shulin (Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan) and Abbas Sarfaraz Khan (Minister for Kashmir Affairs, Northern Areas, States and Frontier Regions) signed and swapped the hand-over certificates for humanitarian aid worth 2 million RMB. The donations include tents, generators, cooking utensils and other necessities.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcsap0020010804dw8t005wz&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010714dx4600co2&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/200107/05/eng20010705_74279.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://doc.bjreview.com/s-br/gh/2001.29-observacion-1.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://reliefweb.int/report/afghanistan/china-extends-aid-afghan-refugees, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://reliefweb.int/report/afghanistan/afghanistan-weekly-update-no-419, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.afghanistannewscenter.com/news/2001/july/jul3c2001.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Peshawar Division is coded in this row. The money and goods to support Afghani refugees went to Peshawar Division, where they were living.
name: Peshawar

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 27.5 million interest-free loan for Advanced Technical Training Centre (ATTC) Construction Project
description: In December 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 27.5 million interest-free loan agreement for the construction of the Advanced Technical Training Center (ATTC). The purpose of the centre is to provide advance training facilities to the people of the Northwestern Frontier Province (NWFP) in field of industrial electronics, specialized welding techniques, computer maintenance and other mechanical training. The project was implemented on a turnkey basis. A foundation-laying ceremony took place on January 25, 2002. Then, on July 16, 2003, the Chinese and Pakistani governments signed a certificate for the official handing over of the centre to Pakistan. The ATTC is located in the district of Peshawar in the Hayatabad Industry Area.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020030717dz7g0007j&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/16643/peshawar-nwfp-to-have-network-of-technical-centres-governor-lays-foundation-stone-of-attc, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.eduvision.edu.pk/my_college.php?city=91&institute=1409406136_Government-Advance-Technical-Training-Centre-%5B-Hayatabad%5D&Submit=Search, Other; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010816dwc200y4b&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.google.com/maps/place/Govt+Advance+Technical+Training+Centre/@33.9204942,71.4615717,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38d910514c143c6b:0xa1f0921e899c9e06!8m2!3d33.9204942!4d71.4637604, Other; http://english.china.org.cn/english/scitech/70167.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China provides 2 million yuan to Pakistan for Afghan refugee aid (Linked to #35130)
description: In August 2000, China donated aid worth 2 million yuan to Afghan refugees in Peshawar, Pakistan. The relief included medicine, tents, blankets, and clothes and was delivered to the UNHCR office in Peshawar. The signing ceremony was held by Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan, Lu Shulin, and Chief of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Afghan Mission in Pakistan.

title: China provides 10 million RMB for anti-terror actions
description: In October 2001 China donated to the Pakistani government emergency aid worth 10 million RMB. The humanitarian aid, including tents and blankets, left on October 22, 2001, for the Pakistani city of Peshawar from Urumqi in northwest China's Xinjiang region which borders Pakistan and Afghanistan. Earlier, on October 1, President Jiang Zemin had declared that China would provide 10 million yuan in emergency aid to Pakistan, in support to the country's anti-terror actions. China had also expressed its willingness to cooperate with Pakistan in counter-terrorism efforts.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=xnews00020011022dxam003px&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/english/2001/Oct/20990.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/ce/cegv/eng/rqrd/jblc/t85094.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.rediff.com/us/2001/oct/01ny4.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaembassy.lt/eng/zt/zgfk/t125316.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://lt.china-embassy.org/eng/zt/zgfk/t125312.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020011022dxam009q7&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/english/200110/23/eng20011023_82953.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/20011023/465525.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcapp0020011018dxai008c1&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcapp0020011120dxbk007pt&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.voanews.com/content/a-13-a-2001-10-01-31-china-66941147/377566.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinanews.com/2001-10-21/26/132391.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/chn//pds/ziliao/zt/ywzt/wzzt/2297/2298/t10561.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: In November, 2001, the Chinese government donated relief goods worth 12 million RMB to be used for Afghan refugees in Pakistan. A handover ceremony took place and the goods donated included tents, blankets, quilts, tarps and other materials that were transported to Peshawar on November 5.

title: Chinese Embassy donates $2 million to flood-stricken areas in Pakistan
description: On 1 August 2005, the Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang made a special trip to the provincial capital Peshawar and Lahore provinces, and contributed 2 million dollars to both governments, to go towards the reconstruction works.

title: Dongfang Electric Corporation provides $108.8 million supplier's credit for 96MW Jinnah Hydropower Station Project
description:
In November 2003, Pakistan's Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) signed a $128 million EPC contract agreement with Dongfang Electric Corporation for the construction of 96MW Jinnah Hydropower Project. Then, on November 3, 2003, China Eximbank provided an export seller's credit to Dongfang Electric Corporation to cover 85 percent of the cost of its EPC contract ($108.8 million) with the Government of Pakistan. The remaining 15 percent of the project cost was to be arranged by WAPDA as advance payment to the contractor. Dongfang Electric Corporation then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to provide a supplier's credit to the Government of Pakistan on the following terms: 14 year maturity and 4 year grace period. 
 
 The main components of the project include a headrace tunnel, powerhouse with eight 12-MW low-head pit turbines, a tailrace channel, 132-kilovolt double-circuit transmission line, and 132-kV switchyard. The project is located on the right side of existing Jinnah Barrage, 5 km from Kalabagh town in District Mianwali and 234 km from Islamabad. Construction began on February 18, 2006, and the project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on October 9, 2013. The Chinese project title is 真纳水电站. 
 
 Staff_Note: China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided a $108.8 million export seller's credit to Dongfang Electric Corporation, and Dongfang Electric Corporation then use the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to the Government of Pakistan.

title: China Eximbank provides $474 million buyer's credit loan for Units 3 and 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (or Units 3 and 4 of CHASNUPP) (Linked to Project ID#36237 and Project ID#70728)
description:
In 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed three separate loan agreements for Units 3 and 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (also known as Units 3 and 4 of CHASNUPP and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 3 and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 4): a $474 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, a $1 billion preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement, and an RMB 731 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement. 
 
 The BCL agreement [Government of Pakistan loan agreement #CHINA10-APR] was finalized on April 9, 2010 and it carried the following terms: interest rate of 6 percent, 20 year maturity, 8 year grace period, management fee of 0.75 percent, commitment fee of 0.5 percent and an export credit insurance fee of 7 percent. The BCL is captured in this project.
 
 The PBC agreement [Government of Pakistan loan agreement #CHINA2010-2-109] was finalized on February 22, 2010 and it carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, interest rate of 2 percent, 8 year grace period, management fee of 0.2 percent, and a commitment fee of 0.2 percent. Project ID#70728 captures the PBC.
 
 The GCL agreement was finalized on February 22, 2010 and it carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 8 year grace period, 1% interest rate, management fee of 0.2%, and commitment fee of 0.2%. Project ID#36237 captures the GCL.
 
 China Zhongyuan Engineering, China Nuclear Industry No.5 Construction Company, and Shanghai Nuclear Engineering and Research Design Institute were the contractors for Unit 3 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project. China National Nuclear Cooperation (CNNC) was the contractor for Unit 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project. 
 
 Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC) supervised the work of all four Chinese contractors. As of June 20, 2017, $1.513 billion had been disbursed by China Eximbank for the Chashma Nuclear Power Project 3 and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 4. Chashma 3 (C-3) Nuclear Power Plant was inaugurated on December 28, 2016. Chashma 4 (C-4) Nuclear Power Plant was completed, inaugurated, and connected to Pakistan's power grid on September 8, 2017. Each of these units of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant (Unit 3 and Unit 4) has gross capacity of 340 MW. 
 
 This project is located near Chashma Colony and Kundian town in Mianwali District and Punjab Province. Its locational coordinates are 32°23′25″N 71°27′45″E. For more locational information, see https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chashma+Nuclear+Power+Complex,+Mianwali,+Punjab,+Pakistan/@32.3902778,71.4625,17z/data=!4m13!1m7!3m6!1s0x0:0x0!2zMzLCsDIzJzI1LjAiTiA3McKwMjcnNDUuMCJF!3b1!8m2!3d32.3902778!4d71.4625!3m4!1s0x3926e20fcd5b4855:0xc0edf2e9f8b15fb4!8m2!3d32.3874153!4d71.4685247
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 恰希玛核电3号机组 and 恰希玛核电4号机组.

title: China Eximbank provides $1 billion preferential buyer's credit loan for Units 3 and 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (or Units 3 and 4 of CHASNUPP) (Linked to Project ID#36237 and Project ID#70730)
description:
In 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed three separate loan agreements for Units 3 and 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (also known as Units 3 and 4 of CHASNUPP and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 3 and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 4): a $474 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, a $1 billion preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement, and an RMB 731 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement. 
 
 The BCL agreement [Government of Pakistan loan agreement #CHINA10-APR] was finalized on April 9, 2010 and it carried the following terms: interest rate of 6 percent, 20 year maturity, 8 year grace period, management fee of 0.75 percent, commitment fee of 0.5 percent and an export credit insurance fee of 7 percent. Project ID#70730 captures the BCL.
 
 The PBC agreement [Government of Pakistan loan agreement #CHINA2010-2-109] was finalized on February 22, 2010 and it carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, interest rate of 2 percent, 8 year grace period, management fee of 0.2 percent, and a commitment fee of 0.2 percent. The PBC is captured in this project.
 
 The GCL agreement was finalized on February 22, 2010 and it carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 8 year grace period, 1% interest rate, management fee of 0.2%, and commitment fee of 0.2%. Project ID#36237 captures the GCL.
 
 China Zhongyuan Engineering, China Nuclear Industry No.5 Construction Company, and Shanghai Nuclear Engineering and Research Design Institute were the contractors for Unit 3 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project. China National Nuclear Cooperation (CNNC) was the contractor for Unit 4 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project.
 
 Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission (PAEC) supervised the work of all four Chinese contractors. As of June 20, 2017, $1.513 billion had been disbursed by China Eximbank for the Chashma Nuclear Power Project 3 and Chashma Nuclear Power Project 4. Chashma 3 (C-3) Nuclear Power Plant was inaugurated on December 28, 2016. Chashma 4 (C-4) Nuclear Power Plant was completed, inaugurated, and connected to Pakistan's power grid on September 8, 2017. Each of these units of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant (Unit 3 and Unit 4) has gross capacity of 340 MW. 
 
 This project is located near Chashma Colony and Kundian town in Mianwali District and Punjab Province. Its locational coordinates are 32°23′25″N 71°27′45″E. For more locational information, see https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chashma+Nuclear+Power+Complex,+Mianwali,+Punjab,+Pakistan/@32.3902778,71.4625,17z/data=!4m13!1m7!3m6!1s0x0:0x0!2zMzLCsDIzJzI1LjAiTiA3McKwMjcnNDUuMCJF!3b1!8m2!3d32.3902778!4d71.4625!3m4!1s0x3926e20fcd5b4855:0xc0edf2e9f8b15fb4!8m2!3d32.3874153!4d71.4685247
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 恰希玛核电3号机组 and 恰希玛核电4号机组.

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.6 billion government concessional loan for Unit 2 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (Linked to Project ID #35108)
description:
In March 2003 China and Pakistan signed a memorandum of understanding for the construction of a second nuclear power plant, Chashma II, with a 300 MW capacity at Chashma, Pakistan, where nuclear plant Chashma I was already installed. It pledged to provide $300 million of financing for Chashma II.
 
 On March 31, 2005, the Government of Pakistan signed a government concessional loan (GCL) with China Eximbank worth RMB 1,598,764,499.79 (or approximately $200 million) for Unit 2 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (or Unit 2 of CHASNUPP). The terms of the GCL are unknown. On the same day, the Government of Pakistan signed a $150 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan with China Eximbank for for Unit 2 of the Chashma Nuclear Power Plant Project (or Unit 2 of CHASNUPP) (captured in #35108). This loan carried the following terms: 3% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and 7 year grace period. China Zhongyuan Engineering Company (CZEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The construction of this project started on April 8, 2005. The Chashma II power plant was officially inaugurated on May 10, 2011. 
 
 This project is located near Chashma Colony and Kundian town in Mianwali District and Punjab Province. Its locational coordinates are 32°23′25″N 71°27′45″E.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 恰希玛核电2号机组. This project is linked to a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from China Eximbank that was provided for the same project. See Project ID #35108.

title: China Eximbank provides $1.79 billion preferential buyer’s credit loan for Sukkur-Multan Section of Karachi-Lahore Highway Project (Linked to Project ID #39013 and #54415)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019. More locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/peshawar-karachi-motorway-multan-sukkur-section-construction/1f700a87-cdc9-414a-8353-ce68ddf9f5fd/

name: Multan

title: Syndicate of Chinese banks provides 1.44 billion of debt financing for the Sahiwal 2x660MW Coal-Fired Power Plant Project (Linked to Project #54134) (CPEC, IPP)
description:
In February 2017, a group of Chinese banks (including ICBC, Bank of China, China Construction Bank, Agricultural Bank of China) signed a syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with Huaneng Shandong Ruyi (Pakistan) Energy Ltd. worth $1.44 billion for the Sahiwal 2x660MW Coal-Fired Power Plant Project. This project involve the construction of two 660MW supercritical coal-fired units, with synchronous installation of high-efficiency electrostatic precipitator and flue gas desulfurization facilities. Huaneng Shandong Ruyi (Pakistan) Energy Ltd. is the project company (or special purpose vehicle) that was established by its sponsor/shareholders — Huaneng Shandong Power Generation Co. Ltd. (51% ownership stake) and Shandong Ruyi Science & Technology Group (49% ownership stake) — to assume responsibility for the development, investment and management the two 660MW coal-fired units in Sahiwal. 
 
 The total cost of the project was approximately $1.808 billion and it was implemented on a build, operate, transfer (BOT) basis, in which the power plant's ownership will be transferred to the Government of Punjab after 30 years of operation. The project was financed with a debt-to-equity ratio of 75:25. This project captures the debt financing that supported the project. The estimated terms of the syndicated buyer’s credit loan are as follows: 14 year maturity, 4 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.45%) plus a 4.5% margin (or 4.95%). Sinosure provided insurance for this buyer’s credit loan. For details on the equity portion, see project ID#54134. 
 
 In March 2014, the Government of Punjab issued invitation for bids for six 2x660MW coal-fired power development projects. By May 2014, the consortium of Huaneng Shandong Power Generation Co., Ltd., its subsidiary in Hong Kong, and Shandong Ruyi Technology Group Co., Ltd., had officially obtained the right to develop Sahiwal 2x660MW coal-fired power project. The project site is located about 12 miles from Sahiwal and 9.3 miles from Okara cantonment, just north of the road which connects the two towns, in Pakistan's Punjab Province. Its exact locational coordinates are 30°42′55″N 73°14′20″E. The site spans 690 hectares and it was given by the Pakistani government free of charge. 
 
 A project groundbreaking ceremony was then held on May 30, 2014, with Nawaz Sharif, Prime Minister of Pakistan and Shahbaz Sharif, Chief Minister of Punjab Province in attendance. Project construction began on July 31, 2015. The project achieved its Commercial Operation Date (COD) on October 28, 2017, and was connected to the national grid. PowerChina was the EPC contractor. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: Some sources identify the total project cost as $1.912 billion.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.273 billion grant for Post Flood (N-35, N-5, N-55) Road Rehabilitation Project
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange (LOE) for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. Then, on December 5, 2012, China’s Ambassador to Pakistan, Liu Jian, attended the signing ceremony for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. The project involved the rehabilitation of 460 kilometers of road along the N-35, N-5, N-55 highways that were damaged by floods. 
 
 According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (Fiscal Year 2015/16 Yearbook), the Chinese Government provided an RMB 1,273,000,000 grant for this project. China Railway 17th Bureau Co., Ltd. and China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. Approximately $65 million of the proceeds from this grant agreement were set aside for the rehabilitation and improvement of the Thakot-Raikot Section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. 
 
 This sub-project commenced on September 15, 2013 and its planned completed date was December 20, 2016. China Railway 17th Bureau Group Co. Ltd was the contractor responsible for the rehabilitation and improvement of the 147km Thakot-Raikot section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. was responsible for the rehabilitation of 163 km of road along the N-5 and N-55. Most of these road segments fall within Sindh Province and they include the Sehwan-Dadu City, Khairpur Nathan Shah-Mehar of Indus Highway and Hala-Moro, Pano Aqil-Ghottki, Ghotki-Sarhad and Sarhad-Dharki Sections of N-5. 
 
 Staff Note: One source identifies the size of the grant commitment amount as RMB 1340 million. We use the more conservative of the the two estimates. Note that the Thakot-Raikot section of N-35 is also known as the Shikarpur-Ghouspur & Thakot Bridge to Raikot Section of N-35 and the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project is also known as the Rehabilitation of National Highway Authority (NHA) Road Network Project.

title: China provides in-kind grant of 30 million Chinese Yuan worth of relief material to Pakistan for internally displaced persons (Linked to project #39088)
description: To help Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) of Swat and adjoining areas, the Chinese government has announced further assistance of 30 million Chinese yuan worth of relief materials, Pakistan's Ambassador to China Masood Khan on May 23, 2009. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu explained that the first batch would be airlifted to Pakistan on 27 May 2009.The grant includes water purification equipment, power generator and medicine. More than 1.6 million people had fled from the Swat Valley in Pakistan's North West Frontier Province, where government forces had been battling armed Islamic militants for weeks. In addition, about 215017 internally displaced persons have been staying at 17 relief camps. More than 1.4 million affected people were registered outside the camps. STAFF_NOTE: Previously, China had already given one million U.S. dollars cash in emergency humanitarian aid to Pakistan for the PM's Special Fund for the Victims of Terrorism. For details of this project, see #39088.

title: Confucius Institute opens at Agriculture University, Faisalabad, Pakistan
description: On January 8, it was reported that a Chinese Confucius Centre was established on campus at the University of Agriculture Faisalabad. The Centre offers courses in Chinese language, cooking, and faculty students exchange programmes. As reported on the university's website, the institute was officially launched in 2015, at the presence of the Chinese Foreign Minister H.E Wang Yi, Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Sun Weidong, Speaker National Assembly Sardar Ayaz Sadiq, and Punjab Chief Minister Shahbaz Sharif.

title: China Eximbank provides $37.4 government concessional loan for Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project
description:
The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project (or Pak-China OFC Project) involved the laying a 820 km fiber optic cable line from the Khunjerab Pass on the China-Pakistan border to the city of Rawalpindi via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust. 466.54 kilometers of the route is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers of the route is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, 47.56 kilometers of the route is located in Punjab province, and 18.2 kilometers of the route is locted in in Islamabad Capital Territory. The line connects the Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network with that of Pakistan, which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction. 
 
 The project also involved the installation of 172 km of aerial fiber optic cable from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The total cost of the project was $44 million and China Eximbank financed 85% of the total project cost ($37.4 million) -- through a government concessional loan agreement [ID#GCL-2014-519] at an interest rate of 2%. The project was a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global, and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. The groundbreaking ceremony project took place on May 19, 2016. The project was scheduled to be completed in November, 2017. The project was then completed on July 13, 2018. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 中巴跨境光缆项目.

title: China provides grant for Pilot Project Of Digital Terrestrial Multimedia Broadcast (DTMB) (linked to #72696)
description: According to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance, China and Pakistan signed a memorandum of understanding to expand the Digital Terrestrial Multimedia Broadcast (DTMB). As of 2018, the first phase of the project, a pilot DTMB installed at Remote Backup Service (RBS) in Murree by Chinese ZTE Corporation for demonstration of the Pakistan Television Corporation (PTV) terrestrial network, is completed. The project is financed through a Chinese government grant for an undisclosed amount from the Ministry of Commerce. The feasibility project had a reported cost of 0.70 million RMB and is completed, according to the Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Year Book for 2015/2016. It is recorded in project #72696. According to the CPEC website, as of 2018 the total cost of the pilot project was $2 million, and the demonstration project is with funding from the Chinese side. PC-1 of the Demonstration project approved by CDWP on 2nd May 2018.
sources: http://cpec.gov.pk/others, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_18/13-Transport_and_Communications.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.pk/survey/chapters_17/13-Transport_and_Communications.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Final%20PCP%20Year%20Book%202016-17%20.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/8csdpteq2a5b3lj/2016%20Government%20of%20Pakistan%20Bond%20Prospectus.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/41, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pakistaneconomist.com/2018/07/09/pakistan-moving-towards-digital-future-under-cpec-plan/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mofcom.gov.cn/dl/gbdqzn/upload/bajisitan.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.digitaltvnews.net/?p=29171, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.zte.com.cn/global/about/news/0515ma, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/english/report/2017-06/30/content_743258.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/english/report/2017-06/30/content_743258.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.digitalrightsmonitor.pk/exclusive-the-cpec-plan-for-pakistans-digital-future/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China donates 800 books to Pakistan National Library
description: In December 2009 China, represented by the Chinese Embassy to Pakistan, donated 800 books to the National Library of Pakistan (NLP). The books, covering a wide range of subjects on Chinese culture, arts, medicines, religions and other related topics, have been handed over to Mazharul Islam, Director General Department of Libraries, by Yang Linhai, Chinese Cultural Counsellor.

description: In 2010, the Chinese Cultural Counsellor Yang Linhai presented a huge quantity of books to National University of Modern languages on behalf of the Embassy of China. title: China donates 500,000 doses of H1N1 vaccine to Pakistan
description: On March 15, 2010, China donated 500,000 doses of Influenza A (H1N1) vaccine to Pakistan on an emergency basis to assist Islamabad in dealing with the influenza pandemic.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCSAP0020100126e61q001gu&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://yws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/b/d/201003/20100306830803.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://yws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/b/d/201003/20100306803872.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

GEO_notes: Islamabad received vaccines to deal with H1N1. Islamabad was coded.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 486.3 million loan for a Non-Intrusive Vehicle X-Ray Inspection System (NVIS) Project
description: On December 17, 2010, the Chinese Government to the Government of Pakistan provided an RMB 486,339,000 loan for a Non-Intrusive Vehicle X-Ray Inspection System (NVIS) Project. This loan carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2.5% interest rate. This project involved the acquisition of 24 mobile scanners in an effort to strengthen security arrangements and fight terrorism. These scanners are designed to detect explosives and weapons. However, this project was plagued by various problems and delays. In 2010, the Pakistani authorities delayed the installation of the x-ray scanners in Islamabad after experts declared them 'a health hazard' due to high radiation levels. Then, after some scanners arrived in Karachi, they could not be brought to Islamabad until December 2014 due to a dispute over the payment of customs duties. This project reached completion, but its exact date of completion is unknown. According to the Monthly disbursement of foreign economic assistance for the month of June 2014-2015, the project was completed on March 17, 2016. Staff Note: The Government of Pakistan identification number for this loan is CHINA-2010-308.

title: China donates 510 books to Pakistan International Islamic University Islamabad
description: China donated 510 books on history, sports, society, calligraphy, opera, medicines, heritage and folks arts to the students of International Islamic University Islamabad (IIUI). Some books were on Chinese Culture. For the help of students, China has also donated CDs and films. Cultural Counsellor of People's Republic China handed over these books, CDs and films to IIUI's Chief Librarian.

title: Mayor of Beijing donates 50000 USD for flood relief in Pakistan
description: On 7 September 2010, the Mayor of Beijing, one of the sister cities of Islamabad, gifted Islamabad a grant of 50,000 $ for flood relief operations. The Ambassador of China in Pakistan handed over a cheque to the Chairman CDA, Imtiaz Inayat Elahi Monday at CDA Headquarters. The grant would have been submitted to the Prime Ministers Relief Fund.

Some organizations that received this aid include, All Pakistan China Friendship Association, the University of Punjab, KRL General Hospital, Pakistan National Arts Council, Baluchistan Arts Council, Economic Affairs Division, National Defense College, and the National Agricultural Research Center. The financial value of this aid is unknown.

title: Chinese Ministry of Culture gave in-kind grant of 150000 Chinese Yuan worth of office equipment to Pakistan
description: On December 8, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of Culture gave an in-kind grant of 150000 Chinese Yuan worth of office equipment to its Pakistani counterpart. Chinese Cultural Counselor Yang Linhai and Pakistans Culture Secretary Moinul-Islam Bukhari signed documents for the handing-over of equipment at a ceremony at the Ministry of Culture in Pakistan.

title: China donates 10.5 million Rs of office equipment to Pakistan
description: On 11 June 2005, the Chinese government granted office equipment worth 10.5 million Rs to the Pakistani government to facilitate offices with modern facilities. A ceremony for the signing of an agreement on the handover of the equipment was held in Islamabad, with Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang and Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Secretary Khalid Saeed inking the document on behalf of their respective governments. The office equipment, including 145 computers, printers, scanners, fax machines and photocopiers, was provided under the grant assistance agreement on economic and technical cooperation between Pakistan and China signed in 2001.

title: Chinese Embassy establishes US$29k 'Chinese Ambassador Scholarship' at Quaid-i-Azam University
description: On December 8, the establishment ceremony of the 'Chinese Ambassador Scholarship' was held for undergraduate and MPhil Students at the School of Politics and International Relations (SPIR), Quaid-i-Azam University (QUA), Islamabad. The scholarship has a reported worth of US$29,500. In an academic year, each of the ten selected students will receive Rs 150,000 on need and merit basis. The scholarship was established to help QUA students with financial difficulties and foster Pakistan-China relations.

title: China opens Confucius Institute in National University of Modern Languages (NUML), Pakistan (Linked to project #72682)
description: In April 2005, Confucius Institute was founded by The Office of Chinese Language Council International (Hanban), Beijing Language and Culture University, and National University of Modern Languages in Islamabad. It is the first Confucius Institute based on the all-weather strategic partnership between China and Pakistan, and also it is the first Confucius Institute in Islamic world. In April 2005, the OCLCI(Hanban) and NUML signed the agreement for establishing Confucius Institute in NUML, and held the ritual to reveal its nameplate. In April, 2007, the opening ceremony of Confucius Institute Islamabad was held. This project is linked to #72682, which records scholarships that were awarded by the Chinese Embassy in connection with the Confucius Institute.
sources: http://www.hanban.org/confuciousinstitutes/node_6851.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://nation.com.pk/islamabad/03-Jun-2016/world-model-confucius-institute-opened-at-numl, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/photo/2016-06/03/c_135408760.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/english/education/206705.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.hanban.org/confuciousinstitutes/node_10868.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.numl.info/confucius-institute-islamabad.aspx, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.numl.edu.pk/International%20Collaboration.aspx, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Donates 2.3 million CNY worth of equipment to National Art Gallery of Pakistan
description: In July 2007, China donated equipment worth 2.3 million yuan (over $300,000) to the National Art Gallery of Pakistan. The equipment includes elevators, film projectors, security monitors, tape recorders, computers, printers, fax machines and various books and magazines about China. Chinese Ambassador Luo Zhaohui and Pakistani Cultural Minister G.G. Jamal signed the handing-over certificate on behalf of their respective governments. The donation was made to express the friendly sentiments of the Chinese government and people to Pakistan in view of the two countries' all-weather friendship.

description: In March 2006 Pakistan established its first DNA test laboratory in Islamabad, with the assistance of China, to investigate complicated terrorism and criminal cases. The Chinese government had provided training for scientists in the facility.

title: Chinese government provides RMB 33.1 million grant for F-9 Park Solar Power Supply Project in Islamabad
description:
Under the F-9 Park Solar Power Supply Project, the city authorities in Islamabad installed 3,400 solar panels on a 2.5-hectare parcel of the 750-acre “F-9 Park”, at a cost of approximately $4.8 million. The system aims to provide a constant power supply to one of the city's key recreational attractions at a time when power cuts remain a major problem due to shortfalls on the grid. The solar installation, which produces 870 kilowatts of electricity ─ enough to power the equivalent of 450 homes ─ runs water pumps and sprinkler systems for the park, and provides power for the offices of the Islamabad Metropolitan Corporation (IMC) and Capital Development Authority (CDA), both located within the park. 
 
 The initiative, financed with a RMB 33.1 million grant from the Chinese government, uses batteries to store solar energy to meet lighting and other electricity needs 24 hours a day. The project was officially completed and handed over to the the National Assembly Secretariat on December 15, 2016. China Railways 17th Bureau Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It completed the project two months before its date on completion. The plant has an installed capacity of 0.85 MW, which will be used to power streetlights in the park, lights in the children’s play area, the tennis court, cricket ground and a tube well installed in the park. China Railways 17th Bureau Group is also responsible for maintaining the plant for five years. The plant is comprised of 3,400 solar panels. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the F-9 Park Solar Lighting Project and the Fatima Jinnah Park Solar Lighting Project. The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) records an RMB 45 million commitment value in its fiscal year 2015/16 year book; however, it downwardly revised this figure to RMB 33.1 million in its fiscal year 2016/17 year book.
sources: http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t1425296.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Final%20PCP%20Year%20Book%202016-17%20.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Website%20Year%20Book%202015-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t1425659.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://dailytimes.com.pk/40078/f9-park-goes-solar/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://jjhzj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/y/201612/20161202372234.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dawn.com/news/1302629, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t1425659.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t1425659.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dawn.com/news/1312286, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://en.imsilkroad.com/p/60909.html?catid=540, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://tribune.com.pk/story/1264684/clean-energy-fatima-jinnah-park-goes-solar/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 850 million government concessional loan for Safe City Islamabad Project
description:
In December 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 850 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement on the Islamabad 'Safe City' (平安城市) Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The contractor responsible for project implementation was Huawei Technologies. This project supported the installation of 1,950 surveillance (CCTV) cameras in Islamabad. 
 
 In coordination with Pakistan’s National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA), all the videos and recorded data from the 1,900 surveillance cameras are used to ensure real-time monitoring of people and vehicles at important buildings, roads, key points and major portions of the city’s residential areas. All the data as received from installed surveillance cameras across the city are also transferred to a command and control centre and all of the suspicious people and vehicles monitored in the surveillance cameras are checked in the big data with coordination of NADRA’s data bank. Then, if suspects are confirmed to be dangerous, the command centre promptly conveys instructions to ‘Rapid Response Force’ and allocates forces to the site within three minutes to minimize the possible destruction caused by suspect and to avert any terrorists activity. The Safe City Islamabad project was completed on March 29, 2016.

title: China grants RMB 240 million for China-Pakistan Friendship Center
description:
The China-Pakistan Friendship Center was built in Islamabad through a grant offered by the Chinese government. The Government of Pakistan provided land for the Center, while the Chinese government constructed, equipped and provided human resources for it. The expected utilization by June 2008 was Rs 275.0 million, although the cost increased up to 3 billion rupees. According to the website of Chinese embassy in Pakistan, China granted 240 million RMB for the project.
 
 The Pakistan-China Friendship Center was designed by China Zhongyuan International Engineering Corporation and constructed by Shanghai Construction Group Corporation. It officially started in 2008 and was completed in September 2010. The center is 125 meters long and 94 meters wide, with a total construction area of ​​more than 20,000 square meters and a real total area of ​​more than 50,000 square meters. It is a comprehensive building with multiple functions such as conferences, exhibitions, theatrical performances, cultural exchanges, catering and accommodation.
