title: China sends to Pakistan a 49 member medical team for quake relief
description: In October 2005 China sent a medical team to Pakistan to contribute to the quake relief operations. It reached Chaklala Airbase in Islamabad on Friday 28 Octobers, where it was received by Minister of State for Overseas Division Senator Tariq Azim and Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang. The team was made up of 49 members, including 8/9 female doctors (depending on the Chinese/Pakistani source considered). It brought along medical equipment, and was destined to Balakot area.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCSAP0020051028e1as003ea&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t219067.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t216836.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.people.cn/200511/04/eng20051104_218942.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://fts.unocha.org/flows/32136?destination=donors/2976/flows/2005%3Ff%255B0%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2521%26f%255B1%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522300%253ACHINA%2520-%2520Floods%2520-%2520June%25202005%2522%26f%255B2%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522266%253AINDIAN%2520OCEAN%2520-%2520Earthquake/Tsunami%2520-%2520December%25202004%2522%26f%255B3%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522270%253APAKISTAN%2520-%2520Rains/Snowfall%2520-%2520February%25202005%2522%26f%255B4%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522302%253ASOUTH%2520ASIA%2520-%2520Earthquake%2520-%2520October%25202005%2522, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
GEO_notes: China sent a medical team to help with the earthquake effort in Balakot. Balakot is located in the Hazara District.
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million grant for construction of hospital and school in Baffa after 2005 earthquake (Linked to Project ID#53903)
description: After the earthquake that struck Pakistan in 2005, the Chinese Government pledged to help with reconstruction efforts. On November 24, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 80 million grant agreement, which provided 60 million RMB for the construction of a hospital and school in Baffa. The project involved the construction of a 6,525-square-meter high school (GHSS Baffa) that would cost Rs 487.5 million and a small hospital of 4,400 square meters (THQ Baffa) that would cost Rs 412.5 million. The school would be designed to accommodate 720 students. At the beginning of 2011, an advance team of 6 people from the Shandong Expressway Qilu Construction Group arrived in Baffa and began the project preparation work. Construction started on July 2, 2011. Then, from December 16-22, 2011, a mid-term quality inspection team organized by the Economic Cooperation Bureau of China's Ministry of Commerce inspected and accepted the project. STAFF_NOTE: In 2015, Chinese Government agreed to update the school and hospital buildings by installing waste management and drainage systems, etc. This project is captured in Project ID#53903. The additional 20 million RMB in the 2006 grant agreement was used for emergency flood relief in 2010 (captured in #73381).
sources: http://fp.brecorder.com/2015/12/201512221257985/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.sdhsg.com/main/news/page.jsp?id=3259, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://ihl.cankaoxiaoxi.com/2012/1106/115275.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/EAD/Publication/SR%20Jul-Jun%202012-13%20Final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/SiteImage/Misc/files/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: COded the Rawalpindi Division since the location detail gave Rawalpindi which is a city and capital of Rawalpindi Division
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.273 billion grant for Post Flood (N-35, N-5, N-55) Road Rehabilitation Project
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange (LOE) for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. Then, on December 5, 2012, China’s Ambassador to Pakistan, Liu Jian, attended the signing ceremony for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. The project involved the rehabilitation of 460 kilometers of road along the N-35, N-5, N-55 highways that were damaged by floods. 
 
 According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (Fiscal Year 2015/16 Yearbook), the Chinese Government provided an RMB 1,273,000,000 grant for this project. China Railway 17th Bureau Co., Ltd. and China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. Approximately $65 million of the proceeds from this grant agreement were set aside for the rehabilitation and improvement of the Thakot-Raikot Section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. 
 
 This sub-project commenced on September 15, 2013 and its planned completed date was December 20, 2016. China Railway 17th Bureau Group Co. Ltd was the contractor responsible for the rehabilitation and improvement of the 147km Thakot-Raikot section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. was responsible for the rehabilitation of 163 km of road along the N-5 and N-55. Most of these road segments fall within Sindh Province and they include the Sehwan-Dadu City, Khairpur Nathan Shah-Mehar of Indus Highway and Hala-Moro, Pano Aqil-Ghottki, Ghotki-Sarhad and Sarhad-Dharki Sections of N-5. 
 
 Staff Note: One source identifies the size of the grant commitment amount as RMB 1340 million. We use the more conservative of the the two estimates. Note that the Thakot-Raikot section of N-35 is also known as the Shikarpur-Ghouspur & Thakot Bridge to Raikot Section of N-35 and the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project is also known as the Rehabilitation of National Highway Authority (NHA) Road Network Project.

title: First Chinese International Rescue Team (CIRT) to quake-hit Pakistan
description: A 49-member Chinese International Rescue Team comprising 23 rescuers, 8 medical staff, 18 seismological experts and reporters with six sniffing dogs and eight tons of search equipment reached Pakistan on Oct. 9, 2005 and had worked in Balakot for eight days. As the first team to enter the town of Balakot, it succeeded in saving three Pakistani victims and offered medical treatment to 591 local people. Entrusted by the UN relief coordination center at Muzafarabad, the Chinese team served as a UN sub-coordinator at Balakot and enjoyed very good cooperation with teams from UAE, Germany, Switzerland, Jordan, WHO, etc. The team returned to Beijing on October 20.

title: China Eximbank provides $164.4 million buyer’s credit loan for Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project (Linked to Project ID #52525 and #54424)
description:
On February 19, 2014, China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), a subsidiary of China Communication Construction Co. Ltd., and the Pakistan Ministry of Communications signed a memorandum of understanding on the Phase II Reconstruction and Expansion of the Karakoram Highway (Raikot-Islamabad). Shortly thereafter, CRBC submitted the engineering feasibility study report and preliminary design for the project to Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. Due to the large amount of project and the high total cost of the 487-kilometer Raikot-Islamabad project, China and Pakistan have decided to divide the project into three sections. The first section is Thakot-Havelian section, the second section is the Havelian to Islamabad section, and the third section is the Thakot-Raikot section. 
 
 Then, on April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project: a $966.19 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement, a $164.4 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, and an RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The PBC loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54424. The BCL agreement is captured in Project ID#54423. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#52525. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are PBC169397-CPEC, BCL-CPEC-2016, and GCL16-6575-CPEC, respectively.
 
 This project involved the rehabilitation of a 118 km road segment that runs from Thakot to Havelian on the Karakoram Highway in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. China Communication Construction Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It work was overseen by Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on April 28, 2016. Construction then began on September 1, 2016. The project was completed on November 18, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is KKH二期项目（赫韦利扬-曼塞赫拉). The second proposed section of the highway from Havelian to Islamabad is captured in Project ID #52719. The third proposed section of the highway from Thakot to Raikot is captured in Project ID #53713.

title: China Eximbank provides $37.4 government concessional loan for Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project
description:
The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project (or Pak-China OFC Project) involved the laying a 820 km fiber optic cable line from the Khunjerab Pass on the China-Pakistan border to the city of Rawalpindi via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust. 466.54 kilometers of the route is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers of the route is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, 47.56 kilometers of the route is located in Punjab province, and 18.2 kilometers of the route is locted in in Islamabad Capital Territory. The line connects the Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network with that of Pakistan, which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction. 
 
 The project also involved the installation of 172 km of aerial fiber optic cable from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The total cost of the project was $44 million and China Eximbank financed 85% of the total project cost ($37.4 million) -- through a government concessional loan agreement [ID#GCL-2014-519] at an interest rate of 2%. The project was a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global, and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. The groundbreaking ceremony project took place on May 19, 2016. The project was scheduled to be completed in November, 2017. The project was then completed on July 13, 2018. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 中巴跨境光缆项目.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.273 billion grant for Post Flood (N-35, N-5, N-55) Road Rehabilitation Project
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange (LOE) for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. Then, on December 5, 2012, China’s Ambassador to Pakistan, Liu Jian, attended the signing ceremony for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. The project involved the rehabilitation of 460 kilometers of road along the N-35, N-5, N-55 highways that were damaged by floods. 
 
 According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (Fiscal Year 2015/16 Yearbook), the Chinese Government provided an RMB 1,273,000,000 grant for this project. China Railway 17th Bureau Co., Ltd. and China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. Approximately $65 million of the proceeds from this grant agreement were set aside for the rehabilitation and improvement of the Thakot-Raikot Section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. 
 
 This sub-project commenced on September 15, 2013 and its planned completed date was December 20, 2016. China Railway 17th Bureau Group Co. Ltd was the contractor responsible for the rehabilitation and improvement of the 147km Thakot-Raikot section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. was responsible for the rehabilitation of 163 km of road along the N-5 and N-55. Most of these road segments fall within Sindh Province and they include the Sehwan-Dadu City, Khairpur Nathan Shah-Mehar of Indus Highway and Hala-Moro, Pano Aqil-Ghottki, Ghotki-Sarhad and Sarhad-Dharki Sections of N-5. 
 
 Staff Note: One source identifies the size of the grant commitment amount as RMB 1340 million. We use the more conservative of the the two estimates. Note that the Thakot-Raikot section of N-35 is also known as the Shikarpur-Ghouspur & Thakot Bridge to Raikot Section of N-35 and the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project is also known as the Rehabilitation of National Highway Authority (NHA) Road Network Project.

title: Second Chinese International Rescue Team (CIRT) to quake-hit Pakistan (linked to #35345)
description: On October 29, 2005, the second Chinese International Rescue Team of 38 members arrived in Balatok. The team comprised 28 medical staff, 8 rescue members and 2 seismologists. During the 20-day mission, the team set up a mobile hospital in Balatok area and provided medical care for over 2000 people. The team returned to Beijing on November 17.

title: Chinese Government provides Rs 94 million grant for sanitation facilities at earthquake-affected school and hospital in Baffa (Linked to Project ID#55836)
description:
In 2006, the Chinese Government agreed to build the Baffa Tehsil Headquarters Hospital (THQ Baffa) and Government Higher Secondary School Baffa (GHSS Baffa) in Baffa within Mansehr District, in the Khyber-Pukhtoonkhwa (KPK). It started construction in 2012. Then, in 2014, the Chinese government agreed to provide Rs 94 million in additional grant funding to Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction, Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA) to upgrade the THQ Baffa and GHSS Baffa buildings with additional facilities and equipment. These upgrades were to include a Waste Water Treatment Unit, Medical Waste Burning Facility (Hospital), Drainage for the hospital, Provision for Voltage Stabilizer in the hospital and provision for Voltage Stabilizer in the school. 
 
 An MoU on the project was signed on November 21, 2014. Then, a construction contract was signed on December 18, 2015. Anhui Construction Engineering Group, a Chinese company, was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project handover ceremony was held on November 2, 2017. In its fiscal year 2016/17 yearbook, the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division Year Book records the value of the grant commitment as RMB 5.8 million, which is roughly the equivalent of the Rs94 million (referenced above). 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: For details of the construction of the original buildings, see Project ID #55836.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Final%20PCP%20Year%20Book%202016-17%20.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Website%20Year%20Book%202015-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://fp.brecorder.com/2015/12/201512221257985/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/todayheader/201512/20151201216312.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/todayheader/201711/20171102664540.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ztb365.cn/xm/info-27610.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

title: Chinese Embassy donated computers and printers to a quake-hit city in Pakistan
description: In Pakistan's quake-hit Balakot, Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang and Pakistani Senator Mohammad Afridi attended a ceremony in a college campus and cut the ribbon together. Ambassador Zhang, on behalf of the Embassy, also donated six computers and six HP printers to the college representatives.

title: China Eximbank provides $966.19 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project (Linked to Project ID #52525 and #54423)
description:
On February 19, 2014, China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), a subsidiary of China Communication Construction Co. Ltd., and the Pakistan Ministry of Communications signed a memorandum of understanding on the Phase II Reconstruction and Expansion of the Karakoram Highway (Raikot-Islamabad). Shortly thereafter, CRBC submitted the engineering feasibility study report and preliminary design for the project to Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. Due to the large amount of project and the high total cost of the 487-kilometer Raikot-Islamabad project, China and Pakistan have decided to divide the project into three sections. The first section is Thakot-Havelian section, the second section is the Havelian to Islamabad section, and the third section is the Thakot-Raikot section. 
 
 Then, on April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project: a $966.19 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement, a $164.4 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, and an RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The PBC loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54424. The BCL agreement is captured in Project ID#54423. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#52525. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are PBC169397-CPEC, BCL-CPEC-2016, and GCL16-6575-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 This project involved the rehabilitation of a 118 km road segment that runs from Thakot to Havelian on the Karakoram Highway in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. China Communication Construction Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It work was overseen by Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on April 28, 2016. Construction then began on September 1, 2016. The project was completed on November 18, 2019. 
 
 This 118 km road segment runs from Thakot to Havelian on the Karakoram Highway in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. More locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/kkh-thakot-havelian-section-phase-ii-improvement/681f9d39-0252-44ab-96f5-d1302400a471/.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is KKH二期项目（赫韦利扬-曼塞赫拉). The second proposed section of the highway from Havelian to Islamabad is captured in Project ID #52719. The third proposed section of the highway from Thakot to Raikot is captured in Project ID #53713.

title: Chinese Banks loan 1.41 billion USD for 870 MW Suki Kinari Hydropower Project in Pakistan (Linked to #54309 and #54319) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The 870 MW Suki Kinari hydropower project developed by Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited will be located on River Kunhar, District Mansehra, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. The project achieved financial close on January 9, 2017. The EPC Contractor is China Gezhouba group Company Ltd. On April 20, 2015, ICBC Chairman Jiang Jianqing signed power project financing agreements for four energy power projects in the presence of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif. The four energy power projects include Suki Kinari hydropower project, Dawood wind power project, Sahiwal coal-fired power plant, and Thar coal-power integrated project. According to the World Bank, the total project cost is 1.8 billion USD, financed through a debt equity ratio of 75:25. China Exim Bank and ICBC each provided a loan of 708.1 Million USD. A Tariff Determination Petition document in 2014 puts the interest rate of the loan at 4.91%, the repayment period at 12 years, and the grace period at 5 years. The construction activities at the site of the project had already commenced and the project was expected to start injecting 3,081GWh million clean reliable and affordable units of electricity each year to the national grid by 2022. The equity financing of the project was to be arranged by the shareholders of Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited, and according to IJGlobal, China Gezhouba Group Corporation, Al Jomaih and Eden each invested 160.09 Million USD. Update: The first Sahiwal coal-fired power plant was reported as successfully completed and inaugurated May 2017 by the Prime Minister of Pakistan. The second plant is scheduled to begin energy production in June 2017. Project also received a No Objection Certificate (NoC) from Pakistan's Environment Protection Department.

title: Chinese Government provides $3.5 million grant for establishment of Precision Mechanical & Technology Centre at PCSIR in Lahore
description: In 2007, Chinese Government provided a $3.504 million grant to the Government of Pakistan (Ministry of Science and Technology) for the Establishment of the Precision Mechanical & Technology Centre at PCSIR, Lahore. The total cost of the project was Rs. 220.36 million. The project received additional financing from the Ministry of Science and Technology. Guangdong Construction Engineering Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The centre is equipped with state of the art equipment including CNC Lathe machines, CNC Milling machines, CNC Machining Centre, CNC Wirecut, EDM, Co-ordinate Measuring Machine, Gear Measuring Machine, Gear Hobbing Machine, 3D Arm Scanner, etc. in workshop and Laboratories. It is used to train technical industry professionals.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 7 million for Chinese surgeons to perform 1,000 cataract operations in Pakistan
description:
In December 2010, the Chinese Government pledged that 1,000 cataracts operations would be undertaken by Chinese surgeons. This was declared by the Pakistani Minister of Information and Broadcasting, Qamar Zaman Kaira, during a press conference on Hu Jiantao's visit to Pakistan. On September 28, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange that codified a RMB 7 million grant commitment for this project. 
 
 Then, on December 7, 2011 an 8-member Chinese medical team arrived in Islamabad to carry out the first 500 free cataract operations in Pakistan. The team was led by Mr. Song Xudong, Chief Physician of Beijing Tongren Hospital. The visit was organized by the 'Chinese People’s Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries'. The team stayed in Pakistan until December 18, 2011. The project was part of China's 'Bright Light Tour'/'Bringing Light Tour' [or '光明行'(Guangmingxng)]. Prime Minister Syed Yusuf Raza Gilani and Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Liu Jian visited the patients who received the treatment. 
 
 Then, in April 2012, a second team consisting of 7 eye surgeons -- and led by by Prof Wang Jum from Beijing Tongren Hospital -- arrived in Pakistan. They operated operated upon 250 patients at Mayo Hospital, Lahore from April 18-21, 2012. They later operated on 80 patients at the Civil Hospital of Karachi (KCH). An addition 200 patients (approximately) were registered and they stayed at KCH from April 23-27, 2012. By April 26, 2012, the Chinese surgeons had successfully completed the their 1008th cataract operation in Pakistan.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020101221e6cg0005q&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020101221e6cg0005p&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PMDAIP0020101220e6cj00001&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t779870.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.nihao-salam.com/news-detail.php?id=NzU5, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t779873.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/12/07/city/islamabad/chinese-eye-surgeons-begin-operating-on-1000-pakistanis/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/12/07/city/karachi/anyone-for-a-free-cataract-surgery-the-chinese-are-here/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.nihao-salam.com/news-detail.php?id=NzQ0, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t927110.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t780031.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://pk.china-embassy.org/chn/zbgx/t885368.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://jjhzj.mofcom.gov.cn/article/y/201112/20111207882179.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China donates computers and books to Pakistan
description: In 2000, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan donated computers and books to Pakistan. Some organizations that received this aid include, All Pakistan China Friendship Association, the University of Punjab, KRL General Hospital, Pakistan National Arts Council, Baluchistan Arts Council, Economic Affairs Division, National Defense College, and the National Agricultural Research Center. The financial value of this aid is unknown.

title: China Eximbank provides $203.25 million buyer's credit loan for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project (Linked to Project ID #37280, #57673, and #54420)
description:
On April 27, 2011, the Government of Pakistan first announced its interest in pursuing a project to develop a city-wide train system in the eastern city of Lahore. Lahore, the capital of Punjab province, is Pakistan’s most populous and prosperous province with more than 5 million people. Pakistani officials expected the new transport system, the first of its kind in the country, to substantially decrease road traffic. Then, on April 20, 2015, a commercial contract for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project was signed between Punjab Mass Transit Authority (PMA) and CR-NORINCO [a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO)]. 
 
 Shortly thereafter, on December 21, 2015, the China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed three separate loan agreements for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project: a $203.25 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, a $1,235,480,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement, and an RMB 1,200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) loan agreement. The BCL (Project ID#53820 and loan ID#BC-OLL-2015) has a 5.2% interest rate, 2 year grace period, and a 20 year maturity. The PBC (Project ID#37280 and loan ID#PBC-OLL15-34377) has a 20 year maturity and an unknown interest rate. The GCL (Project ID#54420 and loan ID#GCL-OLL15-20559) has a 2% interest rate and a 20 year maturity. According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division, $672.7 million of this “mixed credit” from China Eximbank had been disbursed as of June 30, 2017. 
 
 The Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project involved the construction of a 27km two-lane metro bus corridor runs through the heart of Lahore along Multan Road, McLeod Road, and GT Road. Upon completion, the Orange Metro Line was expected to have capacity for 30,000 passenger per hour and serve 250,000 passengers per day. CR-NORINCO — a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) — was the entity responsible for project implementation. The project was initially expected to begin by the end of 2014, last for 27 months, and conclude in 2018. However, it encountered various delays. 
 
 The Lahore Development Authority began marking sites for demolition in August 2015, including government buildings, royal tombs, mosques, schools, and residences. Civil works were then initiated by CN-NORINCO on October 25, 2015. Popular protests prompted the Lahore high court to suspend work surrounding heritage sites in January 2016 while the court deliberated the issue. Then, in August 2016, the Lahore high court ruled that the government could not evict people or harm the heritage sites. The Punjab provincial government challenged the ruling, and in April 2017, the Supreme Court reversed its decision, allowing construction to continue under 31 conditions to limit the disruption and damage of the project. This project was ultimately completed on December 10, 2019.
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 巴基斯坦拉合尔轨道交通“橙线”项目. In January 2017, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) also provided a Rs 1.36 billion short-term loan in additional financing for the Orange Line Metro Project in Pakistan (captured in #57673).

 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 巴基斯坦拉合尔轨道交通“橙线”项目. In January 2017, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) also provided a Rs 1.36 billion short-term loan in additional financing for the Orange Line Metro Project in Pakistan (captured in #57673).

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 86 million government concessional loan (GCL) for Paksat-1R Ground Control Station Project (Linked to Project ID#43298 and #72713)
description:
In October 2008, a contract for the construction and launch of Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was signed between Pakistan's Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). The communication satellite was to be constructed with 30 year transponders, 12 in C-Band and 18 in Ku-Band, each of 36 MHz Bandwidth. Then, in September 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a framework agreement. Under the terms of the framework agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide up to RMB 1.385 billion for the Paksat-1R Project. Any subsidiary loans under this framework agreement would bear the following terms: a 2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and a 5 year grace period. 
 
 Shortly thereafter, on October 15, 2009, Deputy Director of the China Eximbank and the Pakistani Ambassador to China signed a RMB 800 million loan agreement for the Paksat-1R Project (Project ID#43298). China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan also signed an RMB 86.5 million loan agreement for the construction of a ground control facility on October 27, 2010 (see Project ID #36953). Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was constructed by the Pakistan Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). 
 
 On August 12, 2011, at the Chinese Xichang Satellite Launch Center, Pakistan’s first Communications Satellite PAKSAT-1R, as part of Pakistan’s Space Programme 2040, was launched. The launch was witnessed by Pakistani Secretary Defence Lt Gen Syed Athar Ali (R), Secretary Foreign Affairs, Salman Bashir, Director General, Strategic Plans Division Lt Gen Khalid Ahmed Kidwai (R) and Ambassador of Pakistan to China, Muhammad Masood Khan. Launched on the Long March 3B rocket, the Paksat-1R satellite has a design life of 15 years with initial goals to provide broadband internet access, digital television broadcasting, remote and rural telephony, emergency communications, tele-education and tele-medicine services across South and Central Asia, Eastern Europe, East Africa and the Far East. 
 
 The satellite successfully took over the operations of its predecessor, the PakSat-1E satellite leased by Pakistan, in geostationary orbit at 38° East. The commercial services of the satellite were inaugurated by the Prime Minister of Pakistan on November 5, 2011 from the satellite ground station located near Lahore. On November 11, 2011, the ground control center was transferred to the Pakistani side for its use.

title: ICBC provides Rs. 1.36 billion in additional financing for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project (Linked to Project ID #54420, #37280, and #53820)
description:
The Government Pakistan first announced its interest in pursuing a project to develop a city-wide train system in the eastern city of Lahore on April 27, 2011. Lahore, the capital of Punjab province, is Pakistan’s most populous and prosperous province. It is home to more than 5 million people. Pakistani officials expected the new transport system, the first of its kind in the country, to substantially decrease road traffic. 
 
 Then, on April 20, 2015, a commercial contract for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project: was signed between Punjab Mass Transit Authority (PMA) and CR-NORINCO [a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO)]. Shortly thereafter, on December 21, 2015, the China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed three separate loan agreements for the Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project: a $203.25 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, a $1,235,480,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement, and an RMB 1,200,000,000 government concessional loan (GCL) loan agreement. 
 
 The BCL (Project ID#53820 and loan ID#BC-OLL-2015) has a 5.2% interest rate and a 20 year maturity. The PBC (Project ID#37280 and loan ID#PBC-OLL15-34377) has a 20 year maturity and an unknown interest rate. The GCL (Project ID#54420 and loan ID#GCL-OLL15-20559) has a 2% interest rate and a 20 year maturity. According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division, $672.7 million of this “mixed credit” from China Eximbank had been disbursed as of June 30, 2017. In January 2017, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) also provided a Rs 1.36 billion short-term loan for the Orange Line Metro Project in Pakistan. The terms of this loan (Project ID#57673) are unknown.
 
 The Lahore Orange Line Metro Train Project involved the construction of a 27km two-lane metro bus corridor runs through the heart of Lahore along Multan Road, McLeod Road, and GT Road. Upon completion, the Orange Metro Line was expected to have capacity for 30,000 passenger per hour and serve 250,000 passengers per day. CR-NORINCO — a joint venture of China State Railway Group Co. Ltd. (CR) and China North Industries Corporation (NORINCO) — was the entity responsible for project implementation. 
 
 The project was initially expected to begin by the end of 2014, last for 27 months, and conclude in 2018. However, it encountered various delays. The Lahore Development Authority began marking sites for demolition in August 2015, including government buildings, royal tombs, mosques, schools, and residences. Civil works were then initiated by CN-NORINCO on October 25, 2015. 
 
 Popular protests prompted the Lahore high court to suspend work surrounding heritage sites in January 2016 while the court deliberated the issue. Then, in August 2016, the Lahore high court ruled that the government could not evict people or harm the heritage sites. The Punjab provincial government challenged the ruling, and in April 2017, the Supreme Court reversed its decision, allowing construction to continue under 31 conditions to limit the disruption and damage of the project. This project was ultimately completed on December 10, 2019. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 巴基斯坦拉合尔轨道交通“橙线”项目.

title: Chinese Ambassador donates 20 computers to Government College University in Pakistan
description: On 20 April 2011, China, through the Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Liu Jian, gifted ten computers, software and other accessories to the Government College University (GCU). The computers have been used by the university to established a high-tech computer laboratory for students at the GCU Postgraduate Library for online access of electronic journals, books and other digital material. GCU Vice Chancellor Prof Dr Ikramul Haq inaugurated the laboratory, while Dean of Arts and Social Sciences Prof Dr Khalid Perviaz, Chief Librarian Abdul Waheed and heads of various departments were also present on this occasion.

title: China grants 214 million Rupees to Pakistan for Engineering Service Centre (linked to #38441)
description: In 2006, the Chinese government donated funds worth Rs. 214 million for upgrading the Tevta Light Engineering Service Centre at Gujranwala. The grant will install Hi-Tech Machinery, and provide facilities for Material Testing, advanced Welding & Fabrication, Hi-Frequency Heat Treatment, Machining of Dies & Moulds, Induction & Vacuum Hardening and Plasma Cutting machinery. The agreement was signed by Mohsin Syed, the Chairman of Tevta, and Zhou Zhencheng, the Economic & Commercial Counsellor of China. First Secretary of Chinese Embassy in Pakistan Yan Jianming, Zonal Manager (North) Group Capt E Muhammad Rashid, Manager Service Centers Akhtar Abbas Bharwana and Manager Public Relations Mustafa Kamal Pasha were also present. The project has not been completed within the planned duration (i.e. 2003-04 to 2005-06), due to the delayed documentation between the Government of the Punjab and China. Works started on 1 July 2007 and ended on 30 June 2009. STAFF_NOTE: According to the Punjab government, the total budget of the project was Rs. 165.880 Million in which Government of Punjab shared Rs.16.187 Millions and the remaining was provided by the Peoples Republic of China. This would put the transaction amount at 149,693,000 Rupees. There is also a discrepancy in the dates, with some sources listing 2006 and others listing 2008.

title: China Eximbank contributes $60 million USD to syndicated buyer's credit loan (BCL) for the 425 MW Nandipur Power Plant in Pakistan
description:
On March 19, 2009, a syndicate of banks (including HSBC, China Eximbank, and BNP Paribas) signed a $150.151 million syndicated buyer’s credit facility agreement with Northern Power Generation Company Ltd for construction of 425 MW Combined Cycle Power Project at Nandipur. The syndicated buyer’s credit facility agreement had a 10 year maturity and it was insured by Sinosure. China Eximbank contributed approximately $60 million through a USD-denominated loan tranche and a Euro-denominated loan tranche. 
 
 Northern Power Generation Company Ltd (NPGCL) is the biggest thermal generation company operating under the overall management of Pakistan Electric Power Company (PEPCO). NPGCL constructed the 425 MW Combined Cycle Power Plant at Nandipur, Nandipur near Gujranwala in the Punjab Province. The main EPC contractor was Dongfang Electric Corporation Ltd with G.E. France serving as a subcontractor. Construction began on October 16, 2008. However, the project was plagued by delays and controversy. In January 2008, under a provision of the 18th amendment, the Government of Punjab, Pakistan signed a $329 million EPC contract with Dongfang Electric Corporation of China to construct the Nandipur Power Project and paid a 10% down payment. Then, a conflict between the Ministry of Water and Power and the Ministry of Law and Justice delayed the project execution for two years from March 2010 to March 2012. 
 
 The Ministry of Law and Justice raised an objection over a violation of Public Procurement Regulatory Authority (PPRA) rules and the granting of the contract to China Dongfang Electric Corporation, which was blacklisted; the ministry further refused to vet the permissions before issuing an explanation of procedures. As a result, machinery worth $85 million remained stuck at the Karachi Port for over two years. In September 2012, the president of Dongfang Electric Corporation, Zhang Guorong, terminated the contract for the construction of the Nandipur Power Project, saying his company had suffered losses worth $85 million. 
 
 In June 2013, Pakistan's Ministry of Water and Power started renegotiating the contract with Dongfang Electric Corporation to resume work on the Nandipur Power Project. After successful negotiations, the firm agreed to resume work on the power station. On July 8, 2013, engineers of Dongfang Electric Corporation arrived in Karachi to inspect the machinery lying at the Karachi Port and to secure its release. Later, work on the project was restarted at an escalated cost. 
 
 After several delays, the project was finally inaugurated by the Prime Minister of Pakistan Nawaz Sharif on May 31, 2014. However, the plant remained operational for only five days after the inauguration and had to be shut down due to mismanagement, conflicts with the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) over high production costs, and the use of inappropriate fuel. Since then, the plant has faced several controversies and operational failures, yielding inquiries and probes into misappropriations within the project. Ultimately, the energy produced by the Nandipur power plant was extremely expensive and the project was shut down after five days of operation. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 南迪普联合循环电站建设项目.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PMPLUN0020110117e71h000b6&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/03/03/business/the-nandipur-power-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tribune.com.pk/story/506409/nandipur-power-project-pakistan-to-finance-plant-through-local-banks/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/02/19/business/nandipur-power-plant-to-be-made-fully-functional-by-june-30/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://tribune.com.pk/story/568824/nandipur-project-govt-intensifies-efforts-to-resume-work-on-power-plant/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/rcai9tp58x8cu1r/IJGlobal%20-%20Nandipur%20Power%20Plant%20Project%20%28450MW%29%20-%20Pakistan.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.transparency.org.pk/pm/mowp/9sept13.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.transparency.org.pk/pm/mowp/26dec13(1).pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.senate.gov.pk/uploads/documents/1492761603_793.PDF, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/184576-Chinese-firm-to-operate-Nandipur-Power-Plant, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://finance.sina.com.cn/roll/20090324/08352747922.shtml , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk2.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/chinanews/200903/20090306123995.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese Government provides $1.3 million grant for Cutlery and Small Tools Industry Centre Upgrading Project in Wazirabad (Linked to Project ID#35837)
description: In 2006, the Chinese Government provides a $1.3 million (11 million RMB according to the Pakistan Ministry of Economic Affairs' Status Report 2008-09) grant to the Government of Pakistan for the upgrading of machinery at the Cutlery and Small Tools Industry Centre in Wazirabad. The agreement was signed by Mohsin Syed, the Chairman of Tevta, and Zhou Zhencheng, the Economic & Commercial Counsellor of China. First Secretary of Chinese Embassy in Pakistan Yan Jianming, Zonal Manager (North) Group Captain Muhammad Rashid (Retd), Manager Service Centres Akhtar Abbas Bharwana and Manager Public Relations Mustafa Kamal Pasha were also present. The respective parties also came to an agreement for the financing of a Light Engineering Service Center (see Project ID #35837). Construction began on July 1, 2007 and ended on June 30, 2009.

title: China Eximbank provides $143.85 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 (Linked to Project ID#71792)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in this project. The second PBC loan is captured in Project ID#71792. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20-year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-projects had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Xinjiang Beixin Construction & Engineering Co. Ltd. and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed, but the exact dates of completion are unknown.

title: China Eximbank provides $448 buyer’s credit loan for the 969 MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydroelectric Project (Linked to project #54087) (non-CPEC, IPP)
description:
On May 22, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $448 million buyer’s credit loan agreement [ID# CN-BCL-2013-01] for the 969MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydropower Project. Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) is a project company that was created to design, construct, own, operate and maintain the Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Project, which is a 969 MW run-of-the-river project in the State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan’s Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) claims that it is the largest hydropower project undertaken by WAPDA since the completion of Mangla, Tarbela and Ghazi Barotha Hydropower Projects. 
 
 The project was designed to divert the water from river Neelum through a tunnel. The tunnel intake is at Nauseri 41 km northeast of Muzaffarabad and the underground powerhouse is being constructed at Chatter Kalas, 22 km south of Muzaffarabad. The diverted water will produce electric power by passing through the turbines and thereafter this water will be released back into the River Jhelum, about 4 km south of ChatterKalas. The project was expected to produce 5.15 billion units of electricity annually. 
 
 According to a March 2018 tariff petition that NJHPC submited to Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost of 506,579 million Pakistani rupees (PKR) is being financed according to a debt-equity-grant ratio of 79:9:11. The total amount of debt financing amounts to PKR 401,416 million Pakistani rupees (PKR), which is roughly equivalent to $3.823 billion. Foreign sources of debt financing include $358 million from the Islamic Development Bank, $181 million from the Saudi Fund for Development, $81 million from the OPEC Fund for International Development, $74 million from the Kuwait Fund for Arabic Economic Development, and $1.024 billion from China Eximbank. 
 
 Two separate loans were secured from China Eximbank: a $448 million China Eximbank buyer’s credit loan (this record) in 2013 and a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan (Project ID#54087) in 2016. The terms of the buyer’s credit loan (BCL) were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.409%) plus a 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the BCL to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 15%. The terms of the preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. 
 
 The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 12%. As of June 30 2017, the PBC loan had been fully disbursed and the $191.067 million of the BCL had been disbursed. The EPC contractor for this project was a Chinese consortium called CGGC-CMEC. It was comprised of Gezhouba Group and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. 
 
 In January 2008, a letter of commencement was issued to the EPC contractor. Project implementation then began on February 9, 2008. According to WAPDA, 90% of the construction works were completed by March 2018. The project was officially completed on April 13, 2018. The project was expected to achieve its commercial operation date (COD) by December 2018. However, it is unclear if the project achieved this goal. By April 11, 2019, the project had injected 2,400 GWh of energy into the national grid. This project was also plagued by controversy. Transparency International Pakistan alleged that the procurement of tunnel-boring machines (TBM), which were meant to speed up the excavation of the remaining tunnels, resulted in $74 million in kickbacks. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 巴尼勒姆杰勒姆水电站.

title: Syndicate of Chinese banks provides $1.6 billion buyer’s credit loan for 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project (Linked to project #54014) [CPEC]
description:
In 2017, a group of Chinese banks (including China Development Bank) signed a $1,642,300,000 syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with Kohala Hydro Company (Private) Limited (KHCL) for the 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project. Kohala Hydro Company (Private) Limited (KHCL) is a project company (or special purpose vehicle) responsible for financing, designing, implementation, and maintaining the 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project. KHCL has a single shareholder: China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Ltd (CSAIL), which is an investment holding company formed by China Three Gorges Corporation on September 30, 2011 in the Cayman Islands to acquire, develop, build, own and operate renewable power generation projects in Pakistan. 
 
 The 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project is part of China–Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) initiative and it is being implemented on a Build-Own-Operate-Transfer (BOOT) basis and financed with a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio. The total project cost is $2,760,170,000,000. A syndicate of Chinese banks is covering 85% ($1,642,300,000) of the total cost of the debt financing for the project ($1,932,120,000). The terms of the syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with China Development Bank and other Chinese banks are as follows: 18.5 year maturity, 6.5 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.6%) plus a 4.60% margin. A syndicate of local Pakistani banks is covering 15% of the total cost of the debt financing for the project. 
 
 The remaining cost of the project is to be covered through an $828.05 equity contribution from CSAIL. To date, a $31.03 million equity contribution has been injected in KHCL by CSAIL (see project #54014). The 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project consists of a dam on River Jhelum, with twin 17.4 km long headrace tunnels which will end in the power house downstream on the River Jhelum. The curved concrete gravity dam with a crest elevation of 910 m, will have a maximum height of 69 meters and a top length of 270 meters. The main power station will be equipped with 4 vertical Francis turbine generator units, each of which has a capacity of 275 MW. An additional 24 MW will run on the ecological flow of the river downstream of the dam. The dam site is located in Siran Village on the Jhelum River, about 3 km downstream of the Kohala Bridge. The power plant is located in Barsala in District Muzafarabad. The catchment area of the dam site is 14,060 km2, with an average annual discharge of 302 m3/s and average annual runoff is 9.52 billion m3. The total installed capacity of the hydropower station will be 1,124 MW, comprising 1,100 MW installed capacity for the main power station and 24 MW (2 x 12 MW) installed capacity for the ecological flow power station. 
 
 A consortium of Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co. Ltd, & China Three Gorges Project Development Co. Ltd was selected as the EPC contractor. Project construction began on September 6, 2018 and the project is expected to reach its commercial operation date (COD) on December 31, 2025. The project company will eventually sell all of the power that it generates to a Pakistani state-owned enterprise — called Central Power Purchasing Agency (Guarantee) Limited — under a 30-year power purchase agreement (PPA). 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The commitment year has been coded as 2017 as the involvement of CDB is confirmed in a EPC Stage Tariff Proposal submitted to NEPRA on June 23, 2017. The Chinese name of this project is 巴基斯坦科哈拉水电项目 (1100MW). As the identity of the other Chinese banks is unclear, the transaction amount is removed, as commercial banks may be involved.

title: Chinese Banks loan 945 Million USD for 720 MW Karot hydropower project (Linked to project #54012, #53675, and #54317) (BRI, CPEC, IPP)
description: Karot Power Company (KPCL) obtained a letter of interest early in May 2007 from the Private Power Infrastructure Board (PPIB) to develop the Karot Hydropower Project. In October 2009, the PPIB approved the Feasibility Study Report of the project and in November 2013, National Electric Power Regulatory Authority granted KPCL a generation license to develop a 720 MW hydro-based generation facility at Karot village, District Rawalpindi, in Punjab province. The project is located on Jhelum River, near Karot Bridge. It is the 4th among 5 Cascade HPPs to be developed along Jhelum River. KPCL is 93% owned by China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, a subsidiary of China Three Gorges Corporation, and 7% owned by Pakistan's Associated Technologies. On January 9, 2015, KPCL completed a EPC Tender evaluation and awarded the EPC contract to Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co., Ltd (TGDC) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation Consortium. The project will be undertaken on a build-own-operate-transfer basis. Construction began in 2015 and is expected to be completed in 2021. The project is designated a priority project under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, and a flagship project under Belt and Road Initiative. Project is part of the $2 billion Karot power projects, focusing on hydro and wind power, under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor reported to be completed by 2018. The project will feature a single power generation complex with an installed capacity will be 720-megawatts with four units of 180-megawatts each. The power structure layout will include a roc-filled dam, spillway, powerhouse, diversion tunnels, head-race power tunnels and a tail-race tunnel end. The project itself is distributed as 80% in Punjab (powerhouse) and 20% in Azad Jammu and Kashmir (reservoirs). According to an interview with the chief accountant from China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, the total cost of the project is 1.75 billion USD, with a debt-equity ratio of 80:20. The project achieved financial closure on February 22, 2017. According to IJGlobal, the 80% debt component was financed by loans from China Development Bank, China Exim Bank, China Silk Road Fund and International Finance Corporation (IFC), each one worth 315 Million USD, along with an additional 100 Million USD loan from IFC. This project records the loans from the Chinese banks. For the equity component, China Three Gorges Corporation invested 316.20 Million USD, while Associated technologies invested 23.90 Million USD (captured in #54012). Sinosure provided loan insurance for the Chinese bank loans. The IMF puts the loan interest rate at 5.11%, with a maturity period of 12 years and a grace period of 5 years. It was additionally reported that there is a 30-year concession period. On April 20, 2015, China's $40 billion Silk Road Fund signed a memorandum of understanding with China Three Gorges Corporation and the PPIB on the development of Pakistan's hydropower project, pledging to finance the project through equity investment in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, and participating in a loan syndicate made up of Chinese banks. As of 2017, the Silk Road Fund has disbursed 1.65 Billion USD. The Silk Road Fund also owns 15% of China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Company as of 2017. On March 14, 2017, IFC announced that it will invest $100 million in the Karot Hydropower Project, and reported that it acquired a 15% stake in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited in 2015. IFC stated that this investment is its first major collaboration with the China Export Import Bank, China Development Bank, and Silk Road Fund. The first unit is projected to begin power generation in 2020, coming online prior to its deadline. The Chinese firm in charge of the project will hand over this project to Pakistani government after the 30-year concession period has ended. Staff_Note: This project is linked to two China Development Bank loans for Karot Wind Power projects under the same $2 billion USD deal (captured in #53675 and #54317).

title: China Eximbank provides $576 million preferential buyer's credit for the 969 MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydroelectric Project (Linked to project #35266) (non-CPEC, IPP)
description:
On September 29, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Neelum-Jhelum Hydropower Project. Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) is a project company that was created to design, construct, own, operate and maintain the Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Project, which is a 969 MW run-of-the-river project in the State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan’s Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) claims that it is the largest hydropower project undertaken by WAPDA since the completion of Mangla, Tarbela and Ghazi Barotha Hydropower Projects. 
 
 The project was designed to divert the water from river Neelum through a tunnel. The tunnel intake is at Nauseri 41 km northeast of Muzaffarabad and the underground powerhouse is being constructed at Chatter Kalas, 22 km south of Muzaffarabad. The diverted water will produce electric power by passing through the turbines and thereafter this water will be released back into the River Jhelum, about 4 km south of Chatter Kalas. The project was expected to produce 5.15 billion units of electricity annually. According to a March 2018 tariff petition that NJHPC submitted to Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost of 506,579 million Pakistani rupees (PKR) was financed according to a debt-equity-grant ratio of 79:9:11. The total amount of debt financing amounts to PKR 401,416 million Pakistani rupees (PKR), which is roughly equivalent to $3.823 billion. Foreign sources of debt financing include $358 million from the Islamic Development Bank, $181 million from the Saudi Fund for Development, $81 million from the OPEC Fund for International Development, $74 million from the Kuwait Fund for Arabic Economic Development, and $1.024 billion from China Eximbank. 
 
 Two separate loans were secured from China Eximbank: a $448 million China Eximbank buyer’s credit loan (this record) in 2013 and a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan (Project ID#54087) in 2016. The terms of the buyer’s credit loan (BCL) were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.409%) plus a 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the BCL to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 15%. The terms of the preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 12%. As of June 30, 2017, the PBC loan had been fully disbursed and the $191.067 million of the BCL had been disbursed. 
 
 The EPC contractor for this project was a Chinese consortium called CGGC-CMEC. It was comprised of Gezhouba Group and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. In January 2008, a letter of commencement was issued to the EPC contractor. Project implementation then began on February 9, 2008. According to WAPDA, 90% of the construction works were completed by March 2018. The project was officially completed on April 13, 2018. The project was expected to achieve its commercial operation date (COD) by December 2018. However, it is unclear if the project achieved this goal. By April 11, 2019, the project had injected 2,400 GWh of energy into the national grid. This project was also plagued by controversy. Transparency International Pakistan alleged that the procurement of tunnel-boring machines (TBM), which were meant to speed up the excavation of the remaining tunnels, resulted in $74 million in kickbacks. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 巴尼勒姆杰勒姆水电站.

title: China Eximbank provides $143.85 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 (Linked to Project ID#71792)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in this project. The second PBC loan is captured in Project ID#71792. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20-year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-projects had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Xinjiang Beixin Construction & Engineering Co. Ltd. and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed, but the exact dates of completion are unknown.

title: China Road and Bridge Corporation sends personnel to clear the KKH after mudslide
description: The China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which is already involved in the project of expansion of the KKH, provided personnel to clear the highway following a mudslide in the Hunza Valley. The CRBC worked jointly with a team of specialists from Ministry of Water Resources of China, Chinese Academy of Chengdu Institute of Mountain Hazards and Environment. The construction work on KKH has restarted

title: China Eximbank provides $37.4 government concessional loan for Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project
description:
The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project (or Pak-China OFC Project) involved the laying a 820 km fiber optic cable line from the Khunjerab Pass on the China-Pakistan border to the city of Rawalpindi via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust. 466.54 kilometers of the route is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers of the route is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, 47.56 kilometers of the route is located in Punjab province, and 18.2 kilometers of the route is locted in in Islamabad Capital Territory. The line connects the Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network with that of Pakistan, which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction. 
 
 The project also involved the installation of 172 km of aerial fiber optic cable from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The total cost of the project was $44 million and China Eximbank financed 85% of the total project cost ($37.4 million) -- through a government concessional loan agreement [ID#GCL-2014-519] at an interest rate of 2%. The project was a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global, and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. The groundbreaking ceremony project took place on May 19, 2016. The project was scheduled to be completed in November, 2017. The project was then completed on July 13, 2018. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 中巴跨境光缆项目.

title: China donates RMB 30 million of humanitarian aid to flood-hit Pakistan (linked to #38551, #36722)
description: On 19 August 2010, China provided Pakistan with additional humanitarian aid worth 30 million yuan, first part of the 'second batch' of aid. After having provided a 'first batch' worth 10 million yuan, at the beginning of the month (project ID #36722), China offered Pakistan additional relief materials, referred to as a 'second batch', meant to provide relief to the North-West region, in particular to the population of the Hunza Lake. The overall value of this second batch was 50 million dollars and it was delivered in two stages. The first part of this second batch, worth 30 million-RMB, arrived in Islamabad, capital of Pakistan, on 19 and 20 of August. Liu Jian, China's ambassador to Pakistan, and Mr. Sibtain Fazal Halim, Secretary of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Statistics, attended the handover ceremony at the airport. The materials were trasported to Pakistan by the PLA airforces and handed to to Pakistan's armed forces. The supplies mainly included tents, compressed food, carpets, generators, and medicine, mineral water, and water purifiers etc. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that the second batch of Chinese-donated in-kind emergency relief materials amount to CNY50 million, corroborating the total amount of the two parts of this second batch (the other part captured in project #38551). This project is linked to project ID #36722 and project ID #38551.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020100820e68k004s9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020100820e68k001e3&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ict4peace.pbworks.com/f/Pakistan_Floods__Jul_2010-OCHA-88TEV6.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020100813e68d0028l&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PMPLUN0020100814e68e000am&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020100813e68d0028l&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AIWNAT0020100816e68d0003g&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ASDEFJ0020110302e6cv0000d&cat=a&ep=ASE, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://pk.china-embassy.org/eng/zbgx/t727575.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://finance.ifeng.com/roll/20100819/2532112.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.sohu.com/20100825/n274462071.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://fts.unocha.org/flows/78008?destination=donors/2976/flows/2010%3Ff%255B0%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2521%26f%255B1%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522504%253ACHINA%2520-%2520Earthquake%2520-%2520April%25202010%2522%26f%255B2%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522516%253ACHINA%2520-%2520Floods%2520-%2520June%25202010%2522%26f%255B3%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522508%253AKYRGYZSTAN%2520-%2520Civil%2520unrest-%2520June%25202010%2522%26f%255B4%255D%3DdestinationEmergencyIdName%253A%2522520%253APAKISTAN%2520-%2520Floods%2520-%2520July%25202010%2522, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

title: China provides USD16,310,011 loan for 18 MW Naltar Hydropower Plant-IV
description:
According to the 2006-2007 Foreign Economic Assistance Status Report on Commitments and Disbursements, the loan agreement for the 18 MW Naltar Hydropower project was signed in December 2001, with a commitment of $16,310,011. Disbursement has been completed as of 30 June 2007. The feasibility study had been completed in 2000. The project was finished in October 2007. The executing agency is KANA. China has taken up at least four other hydropower projects in these areas—Bhunji including the Naltar project and then smaller projects in places like Phendar, Harpo and Yurlbo. 
 
 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: Found on "P" tab of Status Report.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AIWINE0020100905e69500002&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://asianetpakistan.com/official-news/press-information-department/157968/prime-minister-performs-ground-breaking-of-14-4-mw-naltar-v-power-project/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.suchtv.pk/pakistan/gilgit-baltistan/item/32924-naltar-hydropower-project-to-be-completed-by-july-2016.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/Trainings/Status%20Report%20from%20July-June%2007.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dawn.com/news/597545, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ecil.com/projects/details/Feasibility-Study-of-18-MW-Hydroelectric-Project-at-Naltar, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: The Hydropower could be found in the Naltar Valley which is part of the Gilgit-Baltistan region and more specifically the Gilgit Division; Gilgit Division is coded in this row. The hydropower is located in Naltar Vallet, which is part of this division. Gilgit Division is a new division and does not exist in the geoboundaries.

title: China Exim Bank provided USD259 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) for Phase-I realignment of Karakoram Highway at Attabad Lake in Pakistan (linked to #35739 and #72395)
description:
On December 21, 2010, Pakistan's National Highway Authority (NHA) signed a contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. This project, which was also known as the Realignment of KKH at Attabad Lake Project and the KKH Barrage Lake Line Reconstruction Project, had a total length of 24 kilometers and involved the realignment of a portion of the highway that was submerged under water during the Attabad landslide in 2010. The project included the realignment of roads, construction of 5 tunnels with total length of 7.12 km, 78 culverts and 2 bridges (471.8 meters). 
 
 On December 23, 2011, China Eximbank signed a $259 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [PBC-2011-35-186] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. On the same day, China Eximbank signed an RMB 585 million government concessional loan agreement [GCL-2011-47-397] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. The terms of the PBC (Project ID#39030) are unknown. The terms of the GCL (Project ID#72395) are also unknown. Construction began on July 26, 2012. The project was completed on September 14, 2015. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is KKH堰塞湖改线项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). This project is linked to #35739, which captures a PBC loan for the Raikot-Khunjerab section of the KKH.

title: RMB 585 million government concessional loan [GCL-2011- 47-397] from China Eximbank to the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project (Linked to project #39030 and #35739)
description:
On December 21, 2010, Pakistan's National Highway Authority (NHA) signed a contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. 
 
 On December 23, 2011, China Eximbank signed a $259 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [PBC-2011-35-186] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. On the same day, China Eximbank signed an RMB 585 million government concessional loan agreement [GCL-2011-47-397] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. The terms of the PBC (Project ID#39030) are unknown. The terms of the GCL (Project ID#72395) are also unknown.
 
 This project, which was also known as the Realignment of KKH at Attabad Lake Project and the KKH Barrage Lake Line Reconstruction Project, had a total length of 24 kilometers and involved the realignment of a portion of the highway that was submerged under water during the Attabad landslide in 2010. The project included the realignment of roads, construction of 5 tunnels with total length of 7.12 km, 78 culverts and 2 bridges (471.8 meters). Construction began on July 26, 2012. The project was completed on September 14, 2015.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is KKH堰塞湖改线项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). This project is linked to #35739, which captures a PBC loan for the Raikot-Khunjerab section of the KKH. This project involved the realignment of a 24 km road section along the Karakoram highway near Atta Abad Barrier Lake. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.na.gov.pk/cpec/sites/default/files/presentations/20151026-Presentation-For-Parliamentary-Commitee-on-CPEC.pdf.

description: On June 19, 2012, China government signed a letter of exchange (LOE) with government of Pakistan to provide the supply of machinery worthing RMB 45.5 million for the road and bridge construction work undertaken as part of the Karakoram Highway Project at Attabad Lake. The initial project agreement was approved on December 17, 2010. STAFF_NOTE: The supply assistance includes two batches of machinery grants, one is the supply of machinery worthing RMB 45.5 million, captured in this project, the other is the supply of machinery worthing RMB 20 million, captured by project ID#72694.

title: China Eximbank provides $327.74 million preferential buyer’s credit for Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project (Linked to Project ID #39030 and #72395)
description:
On January 18, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $327,740,000 loan agreement [ID#320080001] for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. The loan carried the following terms: 12 year maturity and an unknown interest rate and grace period. 
 
 This project, which is also known as the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Upgrade Project, involved the upgrading of a 335 km segment of the Karakoram Highway runs from Raikot to Khunjerab. This segment was widened from 10 to 30 meters, making it suitable for heavy and long vehicles and allowing it to remain functional throughout the year. The project also involved the construction of 32 new bridges and rehabilitate 27 existing bridges. Its total cost was $491 million. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and the Pakistan National Highway Authority (NHA) were responsible for implementation of the project. National Engineering Services Pakistan (Nespak) served as a consultant for the project. 
 
 A groundbreaking ceremony was held on February 16, 2008. Construction began on August 1, 2008. The project was successfully completed on November 30, 2013. The road work was designed and constructed in accordance with China’s three-level highway standard. Final inspection of the project was was carried out by NHA Inspection Wing. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 喀喇昆仑公路改扩建项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). Some ancillary works were also undertaken by CRBC to realign the highway due to a landslide that happened in 2010. For details on the realignment work on the highway, see Project ID #39030 and #72395. Note that the upgrading and realignment works on the road are jointly called the Phase-I project of KKH Highway.

title: China government grants the supply of machinery worth RMB 20 million for Attabad Lake (Linked to #72693)
description: On June 19, 2012, the Chinese government signed a letter of exchange (LOE) with government of Pakistan to supply machinery worth RMB 20 million for the road and bridge construction work undertaken as part of the Karakoram Highway Project at Attabad Lake. The initial project agreement was originally approved on December 17, 2010. Staff_Note The supply assistance includes two batches of machinery grants, one is the supply of machinery worth RMB 45.5 million, captured by project ID#72693, the other is the supply of machinery worth RMB 20 million, captured by this project.
