title: China Eximbank provides $156.15 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 (Linked to Project ID#53872)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in Project ID#53872. The second PBC loan is captured in this project. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20 year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-project had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Beixin Construction & Engineering Company and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed but their exact dates of completion are unknown.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/EAD/Publication/SR%20July-June%202012-13%20Revised%20on%2009-January-2014%20Final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://pndajk.gov.pk/uploadfiles/downloads/AJK%20at%20a%20glance%202014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://fp.brecorder.com/2011/01/201101301149870/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/hgae5y4fxww3hur/Monthly%20report%202013-14_xls%20July-%20Dec%202013.xls?dl=0 and http://ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/EAD/Publication/jul-oct%202013.xls , Other; https://www.pndajk.gov.pk/uploadfiles/downloads/AJK%20at%20A%20Glance%202011.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://pndajk.gov.pk/uploadfiles/downloads/AJK%20at%20A%20Glance%202012.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/u2y8nlr4zg2pcqb/ERRA%20___%20Donors%20and%20Sponsors%20Cell.pdf?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/p2cc02q1ddwo01h/NESPAK%20National%20Engineering%20Services%20Pakistan.pdf?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ead.gov.pk/PublicationDetail/NWYzMTUwNjItYTgyNi00MGM5LWI3ZTItOTI1MDAwN2FkZWJj, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: Chinese Government provides $1.5 million cash grant for earthquake relief activities in Balochistan (Linked to Project ID#54186)
description: On September 25, 2013, the Chinese Government announced that it would provide emergency relief assistance to the Pakistani government in the aftermath of an earthquake in Balochistan. title: China dispatches 4 army helicopters for flood-relief in Sindh, Pakistan (linked to #36860)
description: In September 2010, China sent four military helicopters to Pakistan to help in the flood relief operations. The helicopters were destined to work in the flood-hit region of Sindh. The helicopters took off from northwest China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region on 21st Septmber and reached Pakistani capital Islamabad on the 22nd for a stopover. Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Liu Jian has received the helicopter Benazir Bhutto International Airport, remarking that it was the very first time Chinese army helicopters have been sent overseas on a humanitarian mission.

title: China Export-Import Bank commits supplier's credit of US$102 million to Pakistan for white oil pipeline
description:
In 2002, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) provided a $102 million supplier's credit to Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) for the White Oil Pipeline Project. Pak-Arab Pipeline Company (PARCO/PAPCO) and China Petroleum Engineering Construction Corporation (CPECC) signed an agreement, under which the Chinese firm would supply equipment and materials for the construction of white oil pipeline from Port Qasim, Karachi to Mahmud Kot, Multan. 
 
 This project involved the construction of a 786 km, 26-inch diameter, high-speed diesel oil pipeline that runs from Karachi to Mahmoodkot. A joint venture company (special purpose vehicle) called Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) was created to finance, design, implement, and maintain this project. Pak-Arab Refinery Ltd. (PARCO ) -- a joint venture company between Government of Pakistan and the Emirate of Abu Dhabi -- holds a 51% majority share in PAPCO, while Shell, PSO and TOTAL PARCO Marketing Limited hold 26%, 12% and 11% equity shares, respectively. 
 
 On August 7, 2001, Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) signed an EPC contract with the China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation – Techno (Pvt) Ltd. Consortium. The total cost of the project was $480 million and it was implemented according to a 75:25 debt-to-equity ratio ($120 million of equity and $360 million of debt financing). 
 
 The project reached financial close in 2002, with China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) providing a $102 supplier's credit and local banks providing additional debt financing to PAPCO. In order to provide this supplier credit to PAPCO, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) secured a $102 million export seller's credit facility with a 10-year maturity from China Eximbank. 
 
 The $481 million project would provide a safer and cost-effective alternative for both crude and refined products transportation and added with the completion of the pipeline a more comprehensive, safer, cost effective, demand responsive and eco-friendly pipeline network will be available to meet the country’s growing needs for energy. The 817 km-long and 26 inch diameter pipeline has an initial capacity of transporting eight million tons refined petroleum products, and 12 million tons white oil per annum. 
 
 The project groundbreaking ceremony was on May 31, 2001. The project reached its commercial operation date on March 1, 2005. It was official inaugurated on completed on August 26, 2005. 
 
 Out of the total cost of $481 million, the foreign component stands at $120 million, while local component stands at Rs 20.657 billion. The debt part of the foreign currency cost is being financed by export credit agencies (ECAs) from China through Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) contractor. Three major banks — HBL, UBL and NBP—will arrange Rs12.5 billion of Rs29 billion White Oil Pipeline Project of PAPCO. Around Rs10 billion would be floated as TFCs (term finance certificates) and the remaining amount would be in the form of redeemable preference shares. The financing arrangement also includes bridge financing of Rs5 billion by the consortium banks to be made available for the project. In this regard, a meeting of the chief executives of NBP, HBL, UBL and PAPCO was held at the NBP office and memorandum of understanding (MoU) was also signed. The Rs29 billion ($480 million) white oil pipeline project is achieving financial close and the entire debt financing of $360 million including Rs12.5 billion in local currency is being arranged whereas equity financing of $120 million is in place. For this project NBP will also provide a foreign currency loan of $18 million and issue a bank guarantee of $102 million for China Exim Bank related to suppliers’ credit from CPECC, which have been selected as EPC contractor for the project.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 在巴基斯坦成品油管线项目. Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided a $102 million export seller's credit to China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC), and CPECC then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to PAPCO. Also, note that one source identifies the face value of the export seller's credit facility as $120 million.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcsap0020010710dx5b001qv&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020010709dx5b02y72&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/30107/banks-to-fund-white-oil-pipeline-project, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050105005528/en/American-Energy-Announces-Purchase-Working-Interest-Pakistan#.VZ1cBu2qqko, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gasandoil.com/news/south_east_asia/ba5dcb7c34cfdf41b5e3754470e8f49f, Other; http://karachi2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/bilateralvisits/200508/20050800298350.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://dar.dargroup.com/Projects/White-Oil-Pipeline-Project-WOPP, Other; https://www.parco.com.pk/our-business/transportation/pipeline-network/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1249358&language=en , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://papco.com.pk/white-oil-pipeline-system/milestones/ , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://papco.com.pk/white-oil-pipeline-system/key-project-information/ , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/b/20050829/09311924123.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cpecc.cnpc.com.cn/cpecc/chuyun1xmxx/201205/d1bff6591fbf439cb42a4733efe0cf59.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.gem.wiki/White_Oil_Pipeline, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaqw.com/news/200905/06/162146.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://fp.brecorder.com/2005/08/20050826316636/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.scribd.com/document/292712576/WOPP-Syndication , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dawn.com/news/13558/chinese-firm-to-get-govt-financial-guarantee-white-oil-pipeline-project , Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs

title: China Gives Pakistan USD $10m for Internal Displaced Person Rehabilitation Program (linked to #72697)
description: According to the Pakistani National Assembly records, in July 2015, China signed an agreement with Pakistan to provide a special grant in cash to support the rehabilitation program for thousands of internally displaced people who were affected by the military operation in Pakistan's northwestern restive tribal region. The agreement, involving a grant of 10 million U.S. dollars, was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Sun Weidong and Secretary of Pakistan's Economic Affairs Division Muhammad Saleem Sethi in Islamabad. The funds were used to support efforts to rehabilitate people of Federally Administered Tribal Areas and promote social development. Specific funding Chinese agency is unknown The agreement commits a total of $129 million USD (RMB 800 million) to be utilized for the Temporarily Displaced Persons (TDPs) and social sector projects in terrorism affected areas of FATA region (captured in #72697). The USD 129 million grant amount included cash grant of USD 10 million for supporting the Pakistani government in rehabilitation of residents in FATA area, while the remaining USD 119 million remained unfulfilled, as projects with FATA Secretariat were being identified for the purpose of reconstruction and rehabilitation in FATA region. These projects include reconstruction, rehabilitation, improvement of schools, irrigation system, highways, electricity, livelihood/ agriculture etc. The special assistance earmarked for rehabilitation of TDPs were recorded as fulfilled. US$ 5 million was received in September, 2015 and remaining US$ 5 million in April, 2016. China disbursed an estimated 1,541.63 million Pakistani rupees, or 11.01 million USD, to Pakistan in 2015-2016, according to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates for Foreign Assistance for 2016-2017. The funds were separated into one special grant of 509.150 million Pakistan rupees and a grant to support GoP in TDP FATA of 1,032.480 million Pakistani rupees.

name: F.A.T.A.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 99.97 million for Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) School Project
description: In 2015, during a visit to Pakistan, President Xi Jinping announced that China would build over 50 girls schools in Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA). On August 13, 2017, the Chinese government fulfilled this pledge through a 99.97 million RMB grant to the government of Pakistan. According to the 2017-2018 Status Report, the project closing date was recorded as August 31, 2018. During the war on terror 1,195 girls schools were affected in the tribal areas, out of which 555 were completely destroyed. Thus far, about 895 schools have been rehabilitated and construction of remaining schools is under process. The Chinese government funding will be used for the construction of 50 new schools.
sources: https://fp.brecorder.com/2018/11/20181120425163/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://web.archive.org/web/20180920172831/http://www.ead.gov.pk/userfiles1/file/EAD/2018/Status%20Report%20July-June%202017-18%20on%2008-Aug-2018.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/09/05/china-to-build-fifty-schools-in-fata/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/227726-China-to-build-50-schools-in-FATA, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Code FATA or Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province since FATA was merged into Khyber and that is the province that was given in the location details and no toher information contradicted this
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China grans $1m USD to WFP to assist FATA (linked to #54372)
description: In November 2017, the 'China South-South Cooperation Assistance Fund' provided $1 million USD to the World Food Program in order to support humanitarian initiatives in Pakistan's Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). This donation will enable food and nutrition assistance to an estimated 158,000 vulnerable and displaced people. This is the first project supported by the fund. The second is a $4m USD initiative to provide housing and commodity assistance, as well as help with the rebuilding of schools in the region.
sources: http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/02/c_136944994.htm, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; https://www.wfp.org/news/news-release/landmark-contribution-china-enables-wfp-assist-158000-people-pakistan, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

name: F.A.T.A.

title: China provides 13,000 tents to quake-hit Pakistan
description: Following the flood that hit Pakistan, China donated 13,000 tents as a contribution to flood relief operations. The materials reached Peshawar on 17 November 2005 through a convoy of 163 trucks which had been travelling via Karakoram Highway. The materials were handed over to Pakistan Army: A 13-member Chinese delegation handed over relief goods to military authorities at Besham. 7000 tents were dispatched to the quake hit areas of Azad Kashmir whereas 6000 tents will be distributed in the affected areas of NWPF.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020051119e1bi00028&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://reliefweb.int/report/pakistan/pakistan-around-rs-8-billion-distributed-among-earthquake-victims-relief, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.china-embassy.org/eng/nyddz/t219910.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: NWFP is coded in this row. It was given tents to recover from an earthquake. It is important to note while the geoboundary exists, this province technically does not exist anymore: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North-West_Frontier_Province
name: N.W.F.P.

title: China donates the 1st batch of humanitarian aid worth of RMB 10 million to flood-hit Pakistan (Linked to projects #38551, #36809 and #36801, and #54097.)
description: In August 2010, following the flood that hit Khyber Pakhtunkhwa region, China donated 10 million yuan to Pakistan in humanitarian aid. The grant was announced on August 01 by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The materials were gathered by the China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) within 48 hours after the government's pledge. The PLA Air Force deployed three Il-76 carriers to transport the materials. The aircraft departed for Pakistan from Shijiazhuang and Nanjing on August 4.The aid included relief materials such as 30 tonnes of medicines and water purifiers, 1,000 tents and 50 power generators, according to China's Ministry of National Defence. The representatives of the two countries involved in the aid transfer were the Chinese Ambassador in Islamabad Liu Jian for China, and Nadeem Ahmed, Chairman of National Disaster Management Authority, for Pakistan. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that the Chinese-donated in-kind emergency relief materials amount to 80 tons, including tents, electricity generators, medicine and water purification equipments, and are worth CNY10 million. STAFF_NOTE: Two more batches of in-kind assistance were subsequently sent in late August and early September of 2010. Linked to Projects #38551, #36809 and #36801. Also linked to #54097.

title: Chinese embassy donates 1 million rupees to Pakistan to fight Dengue Fever
description: On 15 September, Embassy in Pakistan political counselor Huang, met the Chief Minister of Pakistan's Punjab province representatives, to pass a letter of sympathy and a 1 million rupee check in donation to combat Dengue Fever. title: China Export-Import Bank commits supplier's credit of US$102 million to Pakistan for white oil pipeline
description:
In 2002, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) provided a $102 million supplier's credit to Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) for the White Oil Pipeline Project. Pak-Arab Pipeline Company (PARCO/PAPCO) and China Petroleum Engineering Construction Corporation (CPECC) signed an agreement, under which the Chinese firm would supply equipment and materials for the construction of white oil pipeline from Port Qasim, Karachi to Mahmud Kot, Multan. 
 
 This project involved the construction of a 786 km, 26-inch diameter, high-speed diesel oil pipeline that runs from Karachi to Mahmoodkot. A joint venture company (special purpose vehicle) called Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) was created to finance, design, implement, and maintain this project. Pak-Arab Refinery Ltd. (PARCO ) -- a joint venture company between Government of Pakistan and the Emirate of Abu Dhabi -- holds a 51% majority share in PAPCO, while Shell, PSO and TOTAL PARCO Marketing Limited hold 26%, 12% and 11% equity shares, respectively. 
 
 On August 7, 2001, Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) signed an EPC contract with the China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation – Techno (Pvt) Ltd. Consortium. The total cost of the project was $480 million and it was implemented according to a 75:25 debt-to-equity ratio ($120 million of equity and $360 million of debt financing). 
 
 The project reached financial close in 2002, with China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) providing a $102 supplier's credit and local banks providing additional debt financing to PAPCO. In order to provide this supplier credit to PAPCO, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) secured a $102 million export seller's credit facility with a 10-year maturity from China Eximbank. 
 
 The $481 million project would provide a safer and cost-effective alternative for both crude and refined products transportation and added with the completion of the pipeline a more comprehensive, safer, cost effective, demand responsive and eco-friendly pipeline network will be available to meet the country’s growing needs for energy. The 817 km-long and 26 inch diameter pipeline has an initial capacity of transporting eight million tons refined petroleum products, and 12 million tons white oil per annum. 
 
 The project groundbreaking ceremony was on May 31, 2001. The project reached its commercial operation date on March 1, 2005. It was official inaugurated on completed on August 26, 2005. 
 
 Out of the total cost of $481 million, the foreign component stands at $120 million, while local component stands at Rs 20.657 billion. The debt part of the foreign currency cost is being financed by export credit agencies (ECAs) from China through Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) contractor. Three major banks — HBL, UBL and NBP—will arrange Rs12.5 billion of Rs29 billion White Oil Pipeline Project of PAPCO. Around Rs10 billion would be floated as TFCs (term finance certificates) and the remaining amount would be in the form of redeemable preference shares. The financing arrangement also includes bridge financing of Rs5 billion by the consortium banks to be made available for the project. In this regard, a meeting of the chief executives of NBP, HBL, UBL and PAPCO was held at the NBP office and memorandum of understanding (MoU) was also signed. The Rs29 billion ($480 million) white oil pipeline project is achieving financial close and the entire debt financing of $360 million including Rs12.5 billion in local currency is being arranged whereas equity financing of $120 million is in place. For this project NBP will also provide a foreign currency loan of $18 million and issue a bank guarantee of $102 million for China Exim Bank related to suppliers’ credit from CPECC, which have been selected as EPC contractor for the project.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 在巴基斯坦成品油管线项目. Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided a $102 million export seller's credit to China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC), and CPECC then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to PAPCO. Also, note that one source identifies the face value of the export seller's credit facility as $120 million.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=bbcsap0020010710dx5b001qv&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=afpr000020010709dx5b02y72&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/30107/banks-to-fund-white-oil-pipeline-project, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20050105005528/en/American-Energy-Announces-Purchase-Working-Interest-Pakistan#.VZ1cBu2qqko, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.gasandoil.com/news/south_east_asia/ba5dcb7c34cfdf41b5e3754470e8f49f, Other; http://karachi2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/bilateralvisits/200508/20050800298350.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://dar.dargroup.com/Projects/White-Oil-Pipeline-Project-WOPP, Other; https://www.parco.com.pk/our-business/transportation/pipeline-network/, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1249358&language=en , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://papco.com.pk/white-oil-pipeline-system/milestones/ , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://papco.com.pk/white-oil-pipeline-system/key-project-information/ , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://finance.sina.com.cn/chanjing/b/20050829/09311924123.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://cpecc.cnpc.com.cn/cpecc/chuyun1xmxx/201205/d1bff6591fbf439cb42a4733efe0cf59.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.gem.wiki/White_Oil_Pipeline, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinaqw.com/news/200905/06/162146.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://fp.brecorder.com/2005/08/20050826316636/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.scribd.com/document/292712576/WOPP-Syndication , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dawn.com/news/13558/chinese-firm-to-get-govt-financial-guarantee-white-oil-pipeline-project , Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs

title: China granted $400,000 USD for repatriation of Afghan refugees from Pakistan
description: On July 18, 2007, the Chinese government signed the handing over ceremony for a $400,000 USD grant for the repatriation of Afghan refugees in Pakistan over three years. The handover certificate was signed in Islamabad by Wang Chao, Assistant Minister of Commerce, Peoples Republic of China, and Akram Malik, Secretary Economic Division on behalf of their respective governments. The ceremony was witnessed by Dr Salman Shah Prime Minster's financial adviser. The amount will be used for voluntary repatriation of nearly 2.489 million Afghan refugees still residing in Pakistan. Staff_Note: While the BBC Factiva article reports the grant amount as $400 million USD, the Ministry of Economic Affairs shows the amount as $400,000 USD in the 2007-2008 Fiscal Year Book.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020070719e37j001ba&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCSAP0020070719e37j001e1&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/41500096.pdf?_=1465411278519, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://nation.com.pk/01-Mar-2020/voluntary-repatriation-of-afghan-refugees-to-start-tomorrow, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ead.gov.pk/SiteImage/Misc/files/8_UN%20China.doc, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

description: On 7 December 2005 China signed an agreement for the donation of medical instruments and other facilities worth 60,000 dollars to Pakistan. Present at the ceremony on behalf of their respective governments were Mao Siwei, China's charge d'affaires to Pakistan and Ahmed Jawad, Additional Secretary of Pakistan's Economic Affairs Division. title: China government grants RMB 700,000 for the feasibility study of Digital Terrestrial Multimedia Broadcasting (Linked to project #53726)
description: On April 20, 2015, China government signed a Letter of Exchange with Pakistan government for the feasibility study of Digital Terrestrial Multimedia Broadcasting (DTMB) project. Under the agreement, the Chinese government provided an RMB 700,000 grant for the feasibility study. The DTMB project involves a revamped Pakistani communications network including cross border fiber-optic cable and adoption of Chinese digital communications standards. The feasibility study was successful, and the project will be implemented by ZTE and funded by China Ministry of Commerce (recorded in project #53726). STAFF_NOTE: The grant was recorded in the table Annex-II (Chinese Grant Assistance During 2006-15), in the Pakistan Economic Affairs Division 2014-15 Year Book.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/SiteImage/Misc/files/Website%20Year%20Book%202014--15.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cpec.gov.pk/project-details/41, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.digitaltvnews.net/?p=29171, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.zte.com.cn/global/about/news/0515ma, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.chinatoday.com.cn/english/report/2017-06/30/content_743258.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.digitalrightsmonitor.pk/exclusive-the-cpec-plan-for-pakistans-digital-future/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: This project concerns a feasibility study of the Digital Terrestrial Multimedia Broadcasting (DTMB) project. The project will eventually contain a fiber-optic line and other things but nothing was built in this part of the project.

Pakistan detected its first bird flu case in the port city of Karachi in January 2004.

title: China gives in-kind grant of 5 drug-sniffing dogs worth 4.5 million rupees to Pakistan
description: On 9 May 2008, The Ambassador of Peoples Republic of China Luo Zhaohui handed over 5 drug-sniffing dogs, worth 4.5 million rupees, to the Director General of Anti Narcotics Force (ANF) to aid in its efforts to fight narcotics. Secretary of Foreign Affairs Salman Bashir and high officials of the ANF were present on the occasion. The provision of anti-narcotics assistance was to curb the influx of opiates. Luo said the Chinese Government has been supporting Pakistan and the ANF to combat the menace of narcotics for more than two decades. Pakistan had fallen both a victim and become a transit country in narcotic trafficking because of its proximity to Afghanistan.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020080510e45a0002t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

The cash donations were handed over by Mr. Huang Xilian, Charge d’Affaires ad Interim of the Chinese Embassy in his meetings with high-ups of these three Pakistan organizations respectively on October 14.

title: China Gives 131 Scholarships to Pakistani Students for 2016-17
description: In 2016, as many as 131 Pakistani students were awarded scholarships from the Chinese government for the 2016-17 school year to obtain higher-level education from bachelor to Ph.D. level from top Chinese universities. This is part of the over 2000 scholarships awarded to Pakistani students to study in China that year. Out of 131, 107 students were given scholarships on the recommendations of the Ministry of Inter-Provincial Coordination. The students will get educated in different fields in various Chinese Universities, including Computer Science and Technology, Business Administration, Finance, Physical Chemistry, Architecture, Civil Engineering, Broadcasting Communication, International Law, Journalism and so on. STAFF_NOTE: The financial amount of the scholarships is unknown.

The first of these projects was the construction of Pakistani missions in Beijing and Shanghai. As of 2001, construction of the missions was underway, but the current state of this project is unknown. The second project (ID #43973) aims to increase a highway's ability to operate year-round. title: China holds seminar to help South Asian nations reduce poverty
description: In June 2007 China hosted a two week, poverty reduction course at The International Poverty Reduction Center in China for 20 officials from Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. The course focused on rural development and poverty, strategies for regional economic integration, methods to manage poverty reduction funds, and China's experiences with poverty reduction. In addition to the course, attendees traveled to Chongqing Municipality to visit poverty reduction programs. The project is co-sponsored by the International Poverty Reduction Center in China (IPRCC). This course was provided again in the following year.

title: Chinese Embassy sponsors Pakistani participants for the International Students Summer Camp
description:
On July 13, 2017, a sending off ceremony for 20 students and teachers was held, before they left to participate in a 10-day 2017 International Students Summer Camp in Beijing. This camp is sponsored by Beijing Municipal Commission of Education (BMCE). The Chinese Embassy in Pakistan sponsored the Pakistani participants, in collaboration with BMCE and the Beijing International Education Exchange Center. Madam Diana Bao, wife of Chinese Ambassador Sun Weidong, made personal contributions to make this project possible.
 
 According to the Embassy article, the students and teachers will visit the Tianaman men Square, Forbidden City, and Great Wall, taste Beijing roast ducks, try Chinese Calligraphy and traditional painting, Beijing Opera Facial Masks, Paper-Cutting and braiding Chinese knots. As a result of this cultural exchange, this project has representational intent.
 
 The Chinese Embassy in Pakistan had organized the Summer Camp program for Pakistani students and teachers for past 4 years, with a total participation of 83 people. This year, 17 students and 3 teachers were invited, from Sardar Bahadur Khan Women’s University, Hazara School, the City School and Islamabad Model College for Boys.

title: Chinese Experts Dispatched to Help Control the Spread of Poliomyelitis
description: From 2011 to 2012, China worked closely with the WHO and dispatched 15 experts to Namibia, Nigeria, Ethiopia and Pakistan to help control the spread of poliomyelitis.

title: Chinese universities provide help to set up Pak-China University
description: Pakistan and China signed agreement of to set up Pak-China University (PCU) of Engineering Science and Technology (S&T) with an estimated cost of Rs 30 billion. The MoU was signed by Dr Jiang Feng on behalf of the Ministry of Education, China and Dr S. Sohail H. Naqvi, Executive Director of Higher Education Commission on behalf of the Pakistani government. May 9 2008 7 Chinese universities including Qinghua University, Beijing Univeristy of Science and Technology, Beijing Jiaotong Universities, Beijing University of Post and Telecommunication, North China Univeristy of Electric Power Univeristy, Beijing Univeristy of Aeronautic and Astronautic and Beijing Institute of Technology formed the Consortium of Chinese Universities (CCU) to provide trainings for the teachers and help with the construction of schools. STAFF: unsure whether China has funded this project.

It is between Islamabad or Lahore. Even though the project location says Islamabad that location has not been determined.
name: Pakistan

title: CRMASC provides $18.8 million supplier’s credit to Pakistan Railways for procurement of 52,000 metric tons of railway material
description:
On April 24, 2002, a $22.152 million contract for the procurement of 52,000 metric tons of railway material was signed by Pakistan Railways (PR) and China Railways Materials and Supplies Corporation (CRMASC). The contract was signed by Saeeduz Zafar, Chairman of the PR Board, and Liu Guoping, Vice President of the CRMASC. 
 
 15% of the contract amount would be financed by the Pakistan government while the remaining US$18.8292 million would be financed through a supplier's credit from CRMASC. China Eximbank provided an export seller’s credit to CRMASC to provide it with the funding necessary to offer a supplier’s credit to PR. The rails that were procured were heavier than the existing rails of the PR. The usage of these rails was designed to permit the operation of trains at a higher speed, and enhance load capacity. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: According to a 2010 media report, CRMASC successfully exported the railway material to PR, so we have status-coded the project as complete. CRMASC is now known as China Railway Materials Group Corporation.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020020426dy4o000ed&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/29846/pakistan-china-sign-accord-on-railways, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://stock.sohu.com/20100927/n275297133.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded up to the country level since no specific area is mentioned for receiving the loan and multiple areas may benefit from the loan

title: China provides in-kind assistance for flood relief for Pakistan worth CNY200 million
description: On 6 September 2010 the Chinese government pledged 200 million yuan of humanitarian aid in kind to flood-hit Pakistan. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Jiang Yu confirmed the 200-million-yuan aid on the 6th evening. Chinese Ambassador Liu Jian called on Pakistan Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani and informed the latter about the Chinese Government's decision. Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao announced the aid at a UN summit in New York on September 22, said Huang Xilian, the embassy spokesman. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs recorded the project on 07/09/2010 and last updated it on 09/09/2010, suggesting that the project had likely been fulfilled by then.

title: Grant of 15 police pick-up trucks, Pakistan
description: On 14 November 2008, in a ceremony which Ambassador Luo Zhaohui, the Pakistani Prime Minister, and the Pakistani Ministry of Internal Affairs adviser attended, China donated 15 police pickup trucks worth 100 million Yuan. In his speech, Ambassador Luo expressed his appreciation for the protection and personal safety provided to the Chinese-funded institutions, provided by Pakistan, and that China supports the Pakistani government to safeguard the social stability, and the promotion of economic development efforts, emphasising the implementation of aid to Pakistan.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 99.9 million grant for establishment of geodetic datum of Pakistan
description:
In 2011, the Government of Pakistan’s State Bureau of Surveying and Mapping asked the Chinese Government to help it establish a Next-Generation Geodetic Datum of Pakistan. This GIS mapping and surveying project is expected to encourage research and innovation in the areas of economy and society and its linkages would promote cooperation between science and technology, public institutions and government agencies. 
 
 Then, on May 13, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange for this project. The Chinese Government committed RMB 99.9 million of grant funding for this project. As of 2020, the project had entered the implementation stage. The Chinese Academy of Survey and Mapping is one of the organizations supporting the implementation of this project.

title: China donates aid package worth $6.2 million to Pakistan as part of earthquake relief efforts
description: In October 2005, China donated a comprehensive aid package totaling US$ 6.2 million (US$ 1 million in cash and US$5.2 million in kind). It had been announced a day after the 8 October earthquake in Karachi, and had been completely disbursed by 23 October. Nine cargo planes had been sent to Pakistan delivering 9 batches of relief goods. The relief goods include 25,000 blankets, 2310 tents, 7350 cotton padded mattresses, 23,980 towel coverlets, 38,000 bed sheets, 1312 generators, 1272 emergency lamps, 6400 buckets, 12 water purifiers, 20,000 gallons of purified water, as well as 46 tons of medicine and medical equipments. According to press release by the Chinese embassy in Pakistan, the aid was delivered in batches beginning shortly after the earthquake on Oct 8 2005, and had finished at the latest by Oct 23.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=NBBALU0020051216e1am00044&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.china-embassy.org/eng/nyddz/t217938.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://jang.com.pk/thenews/spedition/mkrf/p35.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.cri.cn/2238/2005-10-18/88@277355.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://pk.chineseembassy.org/eng/zbgx/t217936.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China donates the 3rd batch of humanitarian aid worth of RMB 60 million to flood-hit Pakistan (Linked to project #36722, #38551, and #36809)
description:
On 25 August 2010, China donated RMB 60 million emergency humanitarian aid to Pakistan. The measure was announced by MOC official Chong Quan after meeting with Masood Khan, Pakistani ambassador to China. Part of China’s RMB 60 million humanitarian assistance to Pakistan reached PAF Chaklala Base in Islamabad on September 7. Liu Jian, Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan and Sibtain Fazal Halim, Secretary Economic Affairs Division signed the hand-over certificate.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: This is the third and the last batch of humanitarian in-kind assistance offered by China to flood-hit regions in Pakistan. Linked to Projects #38511, #36809 and #36722. These projects are all covered under the umbrella project #54097.

title: Chinese Government provides $10 million cash grant to support flood survivors through Pakistan's Citizens Damage Compensation Program (Linked to Project ID#36984 and #54097)
description: On January 24, 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed a grant agreement to support victims of the 2010 floods in Pakistan. The Chinese Government agreed to provide a $10 million cash grant to support the Government of Pakistan's Citizens Damage Compensation Program (CDCP) for flood survivors. This grant commitment and a $400 million loan pledge were announced by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao while he was speaking at the National Disaster Management Authority in Islamabad on December 18, 2010. STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the $400 million USD loan pledge (#36984) and the umbrella amount for all flood aid from China to Pakistan in 2010 (#54097).

title: Donfang Electric Corporation provides supplier’s credit worth $4.6 million for the acquisition of 69 locomotives (Linked to projects #35120 and #56551)
description:
In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth $100 million to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide export seller’s credits to cover 87.5% of the financial requirements of the supplier credits that two Chinese firms would offer to Pakistan Railways (PR). The remaining 12.5% would be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The terms of the lending package were as follows: 18 year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an interest rate of approximately 5%. 
 
 China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation agreed to sell 175 passenger carriages to PR, while Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) agreed to sell 69 modern locomotive engines to PR (with 15 locomotives being manufactured in China and the remaining 54 being assembled in Pakistan). China was to provide both spare parts and technology. According to a 2003 China Eximbank annual report, it agreed in March of 2003 to provide RMB 650 million (roughly the equivalent of $100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in export seller’s credits to China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation. Then, in July of 2003, its two export seller’s credits to Donfang Electric Corporation worth RMB 680 million and $4.6 million, respectively, to support the firm’s sale and export of 69 locomotives to PR. 
 
 This project captures the $4.6 million supplier credit from Donfang Electric Corporation for the acquisition of 69 locomotives. For details of the RMB 680 million supplier credit from Donfang Electric Corporation, see project #56551. For details of the other supplier credit from CMC involving the acquisition railway coaches, see project #35120. These are linked together because they were signed and implemented simultaneously. 
 
 Staff Note: Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided a $4.6 million export seller's credit to Donfang Electric Corporation, and Donfang Electric Corporation then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to Pakistan Railways.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant for polio eradication equipment
description: According to the Government of Pakistan's Economic Affairs Division (EAD) FY2015-16 Year Book, the Chinese Government provided RMB 50 million for the provision of polio eradication equipment. This project had entered the implementation stage by FY2015-16. The installation of cold storage rooms for the polio eradication materials was underway.

name: Pakistan

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 32.3 million grant for Pakistan's National Seismic Monitoring Network
description: In 2007, following an earthquake in Kashmir, the Chinese Government agreed to fund a National Seismic Monitoring Network in Pakistan. On July 18, 2007, the Government of Pakistan and the Chinese Government signed letters of exchange to codify the RMB 32.2 million grant commitment for this project. Through this project, the Chinese Government agreed to establish National Seismic Monitoring Network in Pakistan, which will include the design of the project, the selection of the stations, the provision of earthquake monitoring equipment and its transportation to Islamabad, the dispatch of technical personnel to Pakistan for equipment installation, and training of Pakistani technical personnel. Project implementation began in 2008 and ended in 2013. The Pakistan Meteorology Department (PMD) officially inaugurated a set of seismic monitoring stations on May 16, 2013 in Islamabad.

The grant was designated for the Ministry of Interior for purchasing security equipment. The project number, as noted by the Economic Affairs Division is 'CHINA-17-SECEQP.' The official closing date for the financing of the project is August 31, 2018.

title: China donates US$5 million in cash to assist Pakistan in flood relief (linked to project #37183)
description: In October 2011, the Chinese Government agreed to provide $5 million of cash assistance to support flood relief activities, in addition to the humanitarian assistance (captured in Project ID#37183) that it had already provided. The handover certificate for this cash grant was issued on November 28, 2011.

title: China provides 30 million RMB worth of supplies for earthquake relief (linked to #53542)
description: On September 25, 2013, the Chinese government decided to provide emergency relief assistance to the Pakistani government for earthquake aftermath. The assistance includes $1.5 million USD (captured in project #53542) and supplies worth 30 million yuan. On September 29, 2013, the first batch of materials arrived in Pakistan. A 7.7 magnitude earthquake hit Pakistan's southwest province, leaving at least 348 people dead.

title: Chinese Government provides 20 million RMB grant in emergency flood assistance to Pakistan
description: On November 24, 2006, the Chinese government signed an 80 million RMB grant agreement with the government of Pakistan, which allocated 60 million RMB to the construction of a hospital and a school in Baffa (captured in #55836) and 20 million to emergency flood relief in 2010. This project captures the 20 million RMB component of the grant.

title: China grants Pakistan 2.5 million USD worth of relief aid for quake victims
description: China sent relief goods worth 2.5 million dollars for the 2006 Pakistani earthquake victims. The relief goods consisted of 3,300 cotton tents and 33,000 blankets. The first consignment of the relief goods had already reached on 30th December, Radio China reported. This consignment was airlifted in 4 batches to Islamabad from Dec. 29, 2005 to Jan. 1, 2006.

title: Chinese Government provides interest-free loan for 10 mobile fumigation chambers
description: On July 23, 2003, China agreed to provide an interest-free economic aid loan worth Rs.88 Million for the supply of 10 Mobile Fumigation Chambers with 4 Truck Heads to Pakistan. The equipment would be used by the department of Plant Protection for fumigation of exportable commodities mandated by International Plant Quarantine Convention and rules. Joint Secretary, Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Mr. Zaheer Ahmed and Economic and Commercial Counsellor, Mr. Ma Changlin, signed the agreement on behalf of their respective governments. The Mobile Fumigation Chambers would facilitate the exporters in exporting agriculture commodities under up graded quarantine measures. This project would also help streamline and augment Pakistani exports after meeting WTO conditions of health, quality, and standards of the products.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PAPRIN0020030725dz7n0003k&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Pakistan was given a supply of 10 Mobile Fumigation Chambers with 4 Truck Heads. There was no information about where these chambers were used so it was coded up to Pakistan.

STAFF_NOTE: Days after the transfer of cash assistance, China announced that it would provide an additional CNY30 million in-kind assistance to help IDPs in Pakistan. For details of this project, see #35903.

title: Chinese Government provides $1.2 million grant for Pakistani law enforcement agencies
description: On September 27, 2011, a meeting in Islamabad between the Pakistani Interior Minister Rehman Malik, Chinese Vice Premier Meng Jianzhu, and Pakistani Army Chief Gen. Ashfaq Kayani resulted in the announcement that the Chinese government would provide a grant to Pakistani law enforcement agencies. The grant, worth 1.2 million USD, was committed to strengthen ties and with an underlying goal of fighting terrorism.

title: China commits to grant of 4.15 million Chinese Yuan to Pakistan for Collaborative Hybrid Rice Breeding Project
description: China committed grant of 4.15 million Chinese Yuan to Pakistan for Hybrid Rice breeding. The agreement for the project was signed in Pakistan on April 6, 2001. The project would lead to transfer of technology and would be undertaken by the ARC. An Min, visiting Chinese vice Minister for Trade & Economic Cooperation and Nawid Ahsan, Secretary, Economic affairs division signed and exchanged letters on behalf of their respective governments for Pak-China Collaborative Hybrid Rice Breeding Project.

title: coded up to the country level since a more granular location could be found in regards to where the relief materials were going to. China granted money to Afghan refugees living in Pakistan. There was no information on where the refugees live in Pakistan.
description: On October 21, 2001, China donated an in-kind grant of relief materials worth 4 million Chinese Yuan for Afghan refugees in Pakistan. The aid will be sent via the Pakistani government and the Pakistan office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. The morning of October 21 saw over 50 trucks fully loaded with cargo-containers set out in a long queue from Urumqi, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region for Pakistan. The aid materials, consisting mainly of tents, woolen blankets, cotton-padded quilts, and waterproof canvass, are provided by Daguang Woolen Mill of Aksu, Urumqi Carpet Making Factory in Xinjiang, Beijing Canvass-Making Factory and Beijing Shuangyang Textiles Co. Ltd. The particular job is handled by Xinjiang Corporation for International Cooperation and Xintian International Eco-tech Cooperation (Group) Co. Ltd.

title: Bank of China provides US$500 million to Pakistan for balance of payment obligations
description: In the 2001 fiscal year, the Pakistani government needed to generate US$3.58 billion to plug the resource gap in the external finance sector. According to an official in the Ministry of Finance, the resource gap would mainly be bridged by rolling over different existing loans and credits currently deposited with the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP). A sum of US$500 million had been received by the Bank of China as a rollover facility to be utilised for balance of payment obligations. Additionally, US$250 million has been provided by the government of Kuwait, US$300 million by the government of United Arab Emirates.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=paprin0020010726dx7n000ij&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.imf.org/external/np/loi/2000/pak/01/, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
GEO_notes: Since no specific area is mentioned for receiving the funding and multiple areas may benefit from the funding, the project is coded up to country level
name: Pakistan

title: China Development Bank provides $700 million loan for balance of payments support
description: On September 20, 2016, China Development Bank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $700 million short-term loan agreement to prevent a balance of payments crisis. This loan carried the following terms: 3 year maturity and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 302 basis points. STAFF_NOTE: The interest_rate field was calculated for the 6-month LIBOR in 2016 (1.058%) and adding that to 302 basis points (3.02%).

title: China provides $500 million to Pakistan via a SAFE deposit loan in 2009 (linked to #73340)
description: In January 2009, the People's Bank of China loaned 500,000,000 USD to Pakistan through State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) deposits. The full terms of the loan are unclear, however it reached maturity in January 2017 and was repaid in full by Pakistan. This project is a subproject of #73340, which encapsulates several SAFE deposits made by China in Pakistan. The loan was earmarked for the shoring up of foreign currency reserves, however it remains unclear if it was used for this purpose.

GEO_notes: Since no specific area is mentioned for receiving the loan and multiple areas may benefit from the loan, the project is coded up to country level
name: Pakistan

title: Chinese Government provides $500 million loan to boost Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves
description: In November 2008, following the visit of President Asif Ali Zardari to Beijing, the Chinese Government agreed to provide a $500 million loan to address an acute balance of payments crisis and help the Government of Pakistan pay for its imports and repay its debts. The deposit was set aside build foreign reserves. It was not to be used for budgetary purposes. The maturity of the loan was 18 months. The Government of Pakistan received the loan on January 23, 2009. Staff_Note: This $500 million loan (deposit) is separate from the one that the Chinese Government provided to the State Bank of Pakistan in June 2008.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=LBA0000020090126e51q000rp&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCSAP0020090125e51p0002t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.geo.tv/1-24-2009/33453.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dawn.com/news/340492/pakistan-receives-601m-from-china-us, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122660181953225067, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=WDAN000020081117e4bh0000e&cat=a&ep=ASE, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XIFINN0020081114e4be001p5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=J000000020081114e4be0001z&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCSAP0020081114e4be0002t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AIWNAT0020081124e4bd0004t&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=DJI0000020081113e4bd0015j&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=UNNIND0020090102e5110005o&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.com.cn/news/txt/2008-11/17/content_16778846.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL34742.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/EAD/Publication/SR%20July-June%202012-13%20Revised%20on%2009-January-2014%20Final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

name: Pakistan

title: China provides $500 million to Pakistan via a SAFE deposit loan in 2012 (linked to #73340)
description: In June 2012, the People's Bank of China loaned Pakistan 500 million USD through a State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) deposit in the State Bank of Pakistan. The loan was supposed to be earmarked for the increase of Pakistan's foreign currency reserves, although there is no confirmation that it was used for this purpose. The maturity date was originally set for the first week of June 2018, however China agreed to roll over the maturity date for another year. For this additional year, the interest rate on the loan was set at 1%, although the original interest rate remains unclear. In 2020, Pakistani official sources indicated that the loan had been repaid in full.

title: China Development Bank loans $196 Million to Habib Bank Limited in Pakistan
description: On June 15, 2017, the China Development Bank loaned $196 million USD to Habib Bank Limited (HBL), a commercial bank in Pakistan. The principal amount is payable in six installments from December 2017 to June 2020. The interest rate for the loan has been set at LIBOR (1.16%) + 2.45% and is payable semi-annually. The purpose of the loan was to expand Habib Bank's offshore operations and to finance energy projects. According to the financial report, Habib Bank began paying off its installments from December 2017. HBL is the only bank in Pakistan having branches in China (Urumqi) and in Gwadar, Pakistan. The bank has been working actively in China with plans to leverage maximum opportunities of projects under China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). Staff_Note: The 6-month LIBOR rate is calculated as the average LIBOR for the sixth months following June 2017.

title: Donfang Electric Corporation provides supplier’s credit worth RMB 680 million for the acquisition of 69 locomotives (Linked to projects #35120 and #56552)
description:
In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth $100 million to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide export seller’s credits to cover 87.5% of the financial requirements of the supplier credits that two Chinese firms would offer to Pakistan Railways (PR). The remaining 12.5% would be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The terms of the lending package were as follows: 18 year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an interest rate of approximately 5%. 
 
 China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation agreed to sell 175 passenger carriages to PR, while Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) agreed to sell 69 modern locomotive engines to PR (with 15 locomotives being manufactured in China and the remaining 54 being assembled in Pakistan). China was to provide both spare parts and technology. According to a 2003 China Eximbank annual report, it agreed in March of 2003 to provide RMB 650 million (roughly the equivalent of $100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in export seller’s credits to China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation. Then, in July of 2003, its two export seller’s credits to Donfang Electric Corporation worth RMB 680 million and $4.6 million, respectively, to support the firm’s sale and export of 69 locomotives to PR. 
 
 This project captures the RMB 680 million supplier credit from Donfang Electric Corporation for the acquisition of 69 locomotives. For the $4.6 million supplier credit from from Donfang Electric Corporation, see project #56552. For details of the other supplier credit from CMC involving the acquisition railway coaches, see project #35120. These are linked together because they were signed and implemented simultaneously. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided an RMB 680 million export seller's credit to Donfang Electric Corporation, and Donfang Electric Corporation then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to Pakistan Railways.

title: China provides 650 million RMB in supplier's credit for China National Machinery Co to export 175 railway coaches to Pakistan (Linked to projects #56551 and #56552)
description:
In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth 100 million USD to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the contract, the Exim Bank of China will meet 87.5 per cent of the financial requirements of the export supplier credit basis, while the rest will be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The repayment period for the credit is 15 years. The grace period will be three years and the interest rate will be about five per cent. China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation will export the 175 passenger carriages. Another Chinese Company, Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) will provide altogether 69 modern locomotive engines worth 100 million USD to Pakistan within a period of two years. Under the agreement, 15 complete locomotives are to be manufactured in China, while the rest of 54 will be assembled in Pakistan. China will provide both spare parts and technology. 
 
 According to the annual report by EXIM Bank of China of 2003, in March 2003, China Eximbank agreed to provide 650 million RMB (roughly the equivalent of USD100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in supplier's credits for China National Machinery, and later in July, the bank signed a similar deal with Donfang Electric Corporation for two lines of supplier's credit, one of CNY680 million and the other of USD4.6 million, to support the latter's export of 69 locomotives. 
 
 This project captures the supplier credit from China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMC) for the acquisition of 175 railway carriages. For details of the other project, see projects #56551 and #56552. These records are linked together because they were signed and implemented simultaneously.
 
 Staff Note: Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided an RMB 650 million export seller's credit to CMC, and CMC then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to Pakistan Railways.

title: China Eximbank provides $153 million government concessional loan for Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS)
description:
On May 16, 2017, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a governmental concessional loan (GCL) for the Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS) Project. The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division records the face value of the loan [ID#GCL-2017-08-613] as $153 million. GCLs are RMB-denominated loans; however, the RMB value of the loan for this project is unknown. The terms of the loan are also unknown. As June 30, 2017, no disbursement had been made through this loan. 
 
 The 1,200 kg Pakistan Remote Sensing Satellite (PRSS-1), also called Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS), will operate at an altitude of 640 kilometres and will enable Pakistan to meet its imagery requirements in the areas of land mapping, agriculture classification and assessment, urban and rural planning, environmental monitoring, natural disaster management and water resource management for socio-economic development. It will also reportedly be used to provide remote sensing information for CPEC and Belt and Road projects in the region. 
 
 The project contract was signed by China Great Wall Industry Group Co., Ltd. ('Great Wall Company') of China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation Limited and the Pakistan Space and Outer Atmosphere Research Committee (SUPARCO) on April 20, 2016. According to the contract, China Great Wall Company was to provide a remote sensing satellite to Pakistan in the form of on-orbit delivery, along with a ground application system, ground monitoring and control system, as well as on-orbit testing, on-site support, training, insurance and related technical support services. 
 
 The PRSS-1 satellite was successfully launched from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, China, on July 9, 2018. After successful tests in the orbit, PRSS-1 became fully operational on August 14, 2018. The control of PRSS-1 Satellite was successfully transferred to ground control stations in Pakistan, according to a statement issued by the Pakistan’s Planning Commission. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 将巴基斯坦遥感卫星一号. Another satellite called PakTES-1A was simultaneously launched with the PRSS on the same rocket. It is the scientific experimental satellite independently developed by Pakistan, which mainly carries out technical verification work on satellite platforms. Chinese side was not involved in its development except for the launch.

title: China Eximbank provides governmental concessional loan (GCL) of RMB 800 million for the PAKSAT-1R Satellite Project (Linked to Project ID #36953 and #72713)
description:
In October 2008, a contract for the construction and launch of Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was signed between Pakistan's Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). The communication satellite was to be constructed with 30 year transponders, 12 in C-Band and 18 in Ku-Band, each of 36 MHz Bandwidth. Then, in September 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a framework agreement. Under the terms of the framework agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide up to RMB 1.385 billion for the Paksat-1R Project. Any subsidiary loans under this framework agreement would bear the following terms: a 2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and a 5 year grace period. 
 
 Shortly thereafter, on October 15, 2009, Deputy Director of the China Eximbank and the Pakistani Ambassador to China signed a RMB 800 million loan agreement for the Paksat-1R Project (Project ID#43298). China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan also signed an RMB 86.5 million loan agreement for the construction of a ground control facility on October 29, 2010 (see Project ID #36953). Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was constructed by the Pakistan Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). 
 
 On August 12, 2011, at the Chinese Xichang Satellite Launch Center, Pakistan’s first Communications Satellite PAKSAT-1R, as part of Pakistan’s Space Programme 2040, was launched. The launch was witnessed by Pakistani Secretary Defence Lt Gen Syed Athar Ali (R), Secretary Foreign Affairs, Salman Bashir, Director General, Strategic Plans Division Lt Gen Khalid Ahmed Kidwai (R) and Ambassador of Pakistan to China, Muhammad Masood Khan. Launched on the Long March 3B rocket, the Paksat-1R satellite has a design life of 15 years with initial goals to provide broadband internet access, digital television broadcasting, remote and rural telephony, emergency communications, tele-education and tele-medicine services across South and Central Asia, Eastern Europe, East Africa and the Far East. The satellite successfully took over the operations of its predecessor, the PakSat-1E satellite leased by Pakistan, in geostationary orbit at 38° East. The commercial services of the satellite were inaugurated by the Prime Minister of Pakistan on November 5, 2011 from the satellite ground station located near Lahore. On November 11, 2011, the ground control center was transferred to the Pakistani side for its use.

title: China Eximbank provides $114.28 million buyer’s credit loan for purchase of 202 locomotives (Linked to Project ID#35901)
description:
On December 14, 2009, Pakistan Railways signed a $114,284,494 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement with China Eximbank for the purchase of 202 locomotives. Under the terms of the buyer’s credit loan agreement [ID#BLA0928], Pakistan Railways agreed to purchase 205 coaches from China Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). 
 
 According to a 2012/2013 status report from Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division, the amount disbursed through this loan as of March 31, 2013 was $59.94 million. In April 2013, CMC exported the sixth batch of 202 locomotives to Pakistan. As of September 30, 2014, only $200,000 had not been disbursed through this loan.
 
 Staff_Note: This project is linked to #35901, which is a cancelled BCL for locomotives also signed on December 14, 2009.

GEO_notes: This project is coded up to country level since the entire country where the national railway runs through is benfitted by the donation and not one specific division mentioned was benefitted over the other.
name: Pakistan

title: China Eximbank provides $54.2 million loan for acquisition of 1300 freight wagons
description: On April 23, 2002, the China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $54,236,875 loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of 1,300 freight wagons by Pakistan Railways according to Pakistan's Ministry of Economic Affairs. Under the terms of the agreement, 420 wagons would be manufactured in China, and the remaining 880 would be produced at the Moghalpura Railway Workshops in Lahore. This loan reportedly carried an interest rate of 5.25%. The Government of Pakistan's identification number for the loan is PR/2003/1300. China State Railway Group Company, Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. As of April 2005, 130 out of 1300 freight wagons had been delivered, and another 130 were slated for arrival in June 2005. As of 2010, all 1300 freight wagons had been delivered.
sources: http://www.ead.gov.pk/ead/userfiles1/file/EAD/Publication/SR%20July-June%202012-13%20Revised%20on%2009-January-2014%20Final.xls, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.steelguru.com/steel/pakistan-railways-to-import-52-cbus-during-2010-11/154214, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan_Railways , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dawn.com/news/113957/railways-package-deal-with-china-hits-problems , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://openjicareport.jica.go.jp/pdf/11821907_04.pdf , Academic Journal Article; https://www.dawn.com/news/104348/1300-freight-wagons-to-be-imported-from-china-mehar , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ead.gov.pk/PublicationDetail/NWQ1YmNiNWQtMzhhNC00ZTVjLTkyMTQtMzkzZTAwNGM1MGI0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: There was no information given as to which railroads received the updated traincars. The source discusses improvement work on some tracks but does not specify which tracks received the cars so it was coded up.
